Kyle Wiggers, Author at TechCrunch
2023
https://techcrunch.com/author/kyle-wiggers

Kyle Wiggers Senior Reporter, Enterprise Kyle Wiggers is a senior reporter at TechCrunch with a special interest in artificial intelligence. His writing has appeared in VentureBeat and Digital Trends, as well as a range of gadget blogs including Android Police, Android Authority, Droid-Life, and XDA-Developers. He lives in Brooklyn with his partner, a piano educator, and dabbles in piano himself occasionally — if mostly unsuccessfully.

service Kyle Wiggers Twelve Labs is building models that can understand videos at a deep level Kyle Wiggers Load More "speakable-summary\"> "font-weight: 400;\"> "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/wework\/\">WeWork<\/a> is on the verge of filing for Chapter 11 bankruptcy in New Jersey, according to sources cited by The <\/span> "https:\/\/www.wsj.com\/articles\/wework-plans-to-file-for-bankruptcy-as-early-as-next-week-1fdcb6a5\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"> "font-weight: 400;\">Wall Street Journal<\/span><\/a> "font-weight: 400;\">.<\/span><\/p>\n If WeWork does indeed file, it shouldn’t come as a shock to close followers of the f "font-weight: 400;\">lexible workspace provider. WeWork warned in August in its "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/08\/08\/wework-goes-from-a-47b-valuation-to-subtantial-doubts-about-its-ability-to-continue-as-a-going-concern\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">second-quarter earnings<\/a> that<\/span> "font-weight: 400;\">\u00a0\u201csubstantial doubt exists about the company\u2019s ability to continue as a going concern.\u201d<\/span><\/p>\n "font-weight: 400;\">The company has faced a number of challenges for years as demand for its co-working spaces has steadily declined over time. Those troubles compounded during the COVID pandemic when\u00a0<\/span> "font-weight: 400;\">companies abandoned office space and employees began working remotely. Even as some companies have returned to the office, the appetite for WeWork space didn’t rebound to those pre-pandemic days.<\/span><\/p>\n "font-weight: 400;\">Earlier this month, WeWork missed interest payments to its bondholders, and was granted 30 days to come up with those payments, according to <\/span> "https:\/\/d18rn0p25nwr6d.cloudfront.net\/CIK-0001813756\/75fb45d7-d40d-4f34-95e0-51188ec72bb8.pdf\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"> "font-weight: 400;\">a securities filing<\/span><\/a> "font-weight: 400;\">. On October 30, WeWork said it had begun discussions with \u201ccertain stakeholders in its capital structure\u201d such as SoftBank and Goldman Sachs about improving its balance sheet as it took steps \u201cto rationalize its real estate footprint.\u201d<\/span><\/p>\n "font-weight: 400;\">In August, the 13-year-old company announced a net loss of $397 million for the second quarter on revenue of $877 million. While revenue was up 4% year-over-year, WeWork interim CEO David Tolley noted in a statement at the time: \u201cExcess supply in commercial real estate, increasing competition in flexible space and macroeconomic volatility drove higher member churn and softer demand than we anticipated, resulting in a slight decline in memberships.\u201d<\/span><\/p>\n "font-weight: 400;\">The company\u2019s stock was <\/span> "https:\/\/finance.yahoo.com\/quote\/WE\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"> "font-weight: 400;\">down over 47% after-hours today<\/span><\/a> "font-weight: 400;\">, trading at just $1.21 and hitting a new 52-week low. This gave the company a market cap of just $121 million, a stark contrast to the $47 billion valuation it reached after raising $1 billion in its SoftBank-led Series H round in January 2019.<\/span><\/p>\n "embed breakout embed-oembed embed--techcrunch\">\n "wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"0pILKwA92b\"> "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/17\/wework-fires-back-at-competitor-codi-with-cease-and-desist\/\">WeWork fires back at competitor Codi with cease and desist following ‘WeWont’ campaign<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote> "piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n "wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"“WeWork fires back at competitor Codi with cease and desist following ‘WeWont’ campaign” — TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/17\/wework-fires-back-at-competitor-codi-with-cease-and-desist\/embed\/#?secret=vSprtrVfCm#?secret=0pILKwA92b\" data-secret=\"0pILKwA92b\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":" WeWork is on the verge of filing for Chapter 11 bankruptcy in New Jersey, according to sources cited by The Wall Street Journal. If WeWork does indeed file, it shouldn’t come as a shock to close followers of the flexible workspace provider. WeWork warned in August in its second-quarter earnings that\u00a0\u201csubstantial doubt exists about the WeWork, which lets freelancers and other non-traditional workers to become members in a shared or flexible office space, has expanded globally over the last year but continues to suffer large losses. While in 2018 WeWork saw a more than doubling of its sales to $1.82 billion from a year earlier, the company\u2019s losses over that same period also more than doubled to $1.93 billion. | TechCrunch","og_description":"Read the latest news about WeWork on TechCrunch","og_url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/wework\/","og_site_name":"TechCrunch","og_image":[{"width":1200,"height":1200,"url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","type":"image\/png"}],"twitter_card":"summary_large_image","twitter_site":"@TechCrunch","schema":{"@context":"https:\/\/schema.org","@graph":[{"@type":"CollectionPage","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/wework\/","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/wework\/","name":"WeWork | TechCrunch","isPartOf":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#website"},"description":"Read the latest news about WeWork on TechCrunch","inLanguage":"en-US","isAccessibleForFree":"True","hasPart":{"@type":"WebPageElement","isAccessibleForFree":"True"}},{"@type":"WebSite","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#website","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/","name":"TechCrunch","description":"Startup and Technology News","publisher":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#organization"},"alternateName":"TC","potentialAction":[{"@type":"SearchAction","target":{"@type":"EntryPoint","urlTemplate":"https:\/\/search.techcrunch.com\/search?p={search_term_string}"},"query-input":"required name=search_term_string"}],"inLanguage":"en-US"},{"@type":"Organization","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#organization","name":"TechCrunch","alternateName":"TC","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/","logo":{"@type":"ImageObject","inLanguage":"en-US","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","contentUrl":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","width":1200,"height":1200,"caption":"TechCrunch"},"image":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/"},"sameAs":["https:\/\/www.facebook.com\/techcrunch","https:\/\/twitter.com\/TechCrunch","https:\/\/mstdn.social\/@TechCrunch","https:\/\/bsky.app\/profile\/techcrunch.bsky.social","https:\/\/www.threads.net\/@techcrunch"]}]}},"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/60650386"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=60650386"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_battlefield?tags=60650386"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=60650386"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_unified_video?tags=60650386"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=60650386"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2622647,"date":"2023-10-31T14:02:07","date_gmt":"2023-10-31T21:02:07","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2622647"},"modified":"2023-10-31T15:14:19","modified_gmt":"2023-10-31T22:14:19","slug":"google-and-match-group-reach-settlement-in-app-store-antitrust-case","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/31\/google-and-match-group-reach-settlement-in-app-store-antitrust-case\/","title":{"rendered":"Google and Match Group reach settlement in app store antitrust case"},"content":{"rendered":" "speakable-summary\">Google and Match announced today they’ve reached a settlement in the "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/01\/19\/epic-and-matchs-antitrust-case-against-google-heads-to-jury-trial-on-november-6\/\">antitrust battle Match waged against the tech giant,<\/a> even as the court case continues with Fortnite maker Epic Games. As part of the settlement agreement, Match Group — which owns dating apps Tinder, Hinge, OKCupid, Match.com and others — will be able to implement “ "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/09\/02\/google-will-allow-alternative-payment-systems-for-play-store-in-more-countries\/\">user choice billing<\/a>” by March 31, 2024. This feature allows users to pay with other systems besides Google’s own.<\/p>\n Spotify and Bumble were among the initial testers for the new system, "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/11\/10\/google-play-to-pilot-third-party-billing-in-new-markets-including-u-s-bumble-joins-spotify-as-early-tester\/\">first introduced in November 2022<\/a>. Since then, Spotify’s third-party billing option "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/01\/31\/spotifys-third-party-billing-option-has-now-reached-over-140-global-markets\/\"> rolled out to worldwide markets<\/a> as Google expanded user choice billing to "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/11\/10\/google-play-to-pilot-third-party-billing-in-new-markets-including-u-s-bumble-joins-spotify-as-early-tester\/\">more countries outside the U.S.<\/a><\/p>\n The program, so far, has not allowed third-party app markers that charge users for purchases and subscriptions to do away entirely with the commission Google requires. Instead, it offers a small percentage off the standard 15% to 30% commission. Currently, that discount is 4%, "https:\/\/support.google.com\/googleplay\/android-developer\/answer\/12570971\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">per Google’s help documentation.<\/a> The program is also still a pilot open to all developers globally who are selling apps to users in the supported 35 markets where it’s now available. Google has not said when the program will become globally available.<\/p>\n As part of the agreement, Match Group will not be allowed to only<\/em> offer its own billing system — it will offer its system alongside the existing Google Play billing system. Users will be able to choose which way they want to pay.<\/p>\n In addition, the settlement agreement includes a provision that Google will continue to work with Match Group in other areas where the two companies partner, including in Google Cloud and in the use of Google’s AI technologies, a Google spokesperson said. This suggests that the rift between the two tech companies incurred by the lawsuit could have led to more complicated relationships across other areas of both Google and Match’s business.<\/p>\n Like Apple, Google has long stressed that its commission structure is not only based on its ability to process payments for its customers. Instead, it suggests that the fees help to support the entire Google Play and Android app ecosystem, including hosting, app discovery, developer tools and other resources necessary to create an app business.<\/p>\n But as larger companies like Match and Epic have argued, they don’t need the same resources as other developers. In fact, "https:\/\/www.fortnite.com\/mobile\/android\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">as Epic demonstrated<\/a>, they could self-distribute apps and manage their own payments. They believed they should then at least have the option to have a more direct relationship with their paying customers, and Google preventing this was an anti-competitive concern.<\/p>\n “We are pleased to reach a settlement agreement with Match Group,” a Google spokesperson said, in a prepared statement. “This ensures we can continue to provide our shared users the secure, seamless, and high-quality experience people expect from apps on Google Play while maintaining Google\u2019s ability to invest in the Android ecosystem and deliver value across an app\u2019s full lifecycle,” they added.<\/p>\n “Today, the Match plaintiffs and Google informed the court that they have reached a binding term sheet for a settlement of their respective claims against each other in the Match Group, LLC et al vs. Google LLC et al lawsuit. Under the terms, the $40 million placed in escrow will be returned to Match Group and no other amounts will be owed by the Match plaintiffs to Google relating to the claims in the lawsuit for the period ending December 31, 2023,” a Match Group statement added, shared alongside the release of its Q3 earnings results.<\/p>\n Recently, "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/08\/11\/google-pushes-match-for-more-money-in-antitrust-battle-court-filing-states\/\"> Google had pushed Match Group for more money in escrow<\/a>, saying that the $40 million would not be enough to cover the missed payments. (Match had been allowed to escrow funds to cover commissions while the lawsuit was underway.)<\/p>\n Match noted that the parties agreed that by March 31, 2024, its apps will implement Google\u2019s User Choice Billing, reducing its commission payments from 15% and 30% to 11% and 26%, respectively.<\/p>\n “The parties will enter a new partnership agreement that will provide value exchange across their broad relationship, which we expect will essentially offset the additional costs that Match Group brands expect to incur over the three years starting in 2024 associated with the implementation and continued use of User Choice Billing in compliance with Google\u2019s payment policy during that period,” Match Group also said.<\/p>\n In addition to the settlement news, Match Group reported a 9% year-over-year increase in revenue in Q3 to $882 million, with Tinder’s portion up 11% to $509 million.<\/p>\n It’s unclear whether this settlement will prompt Epic Games to also reach an agreement with the tech giant. If it does not, it’s set to go to trial next week to present its arguments.<\/p>\n "embed breakout embed-oembed embed--techcrunch\">\n "wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"qGcXVnzmF8\"> "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/01\/19\/epic-and-matchs-antitrust-case-against-google-heads-to-jury-trial-on-november-6\/\">Epic and Match’s antitrust case against Google heads to jury trial on November 6<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n "wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; News","publisher":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#organization"},"alternateName":"TC","potentialAction":[{"@type":"SearchAction","target":{"@type":"EntryPoint","urlTemplate":"https:\/\/search.techcrunch.com\/search?p={search_term_string}"},"query-input":"required name=search_term_string"}],"inLanguage":"en-US"},{"@type":"Organization","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#organization","name":"TechCrunch","alternateName":"TC","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/","logo":{"@type":"ImageObject","inLanguage":"en-US","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","contentUrl":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","width":1200,"height":1200,"caption":"TechCrunch"},"image":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/"},"sameAs":["https:\/\/www.facebook.com\/techcrunch","https:\/\/twitter.com\/TechCrunch","https:\/\/mstdn.social\/@TechCrunch","https:\/\/bsky.app\/profile\/techcrunch.bsky.social","https:\/\/www.threads.net\/@techcrunch"]}]}},"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/79611524"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=79611524"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_battlefield?tags=79611524"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=79611524"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_unified_video?tags=79611524"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=79611524"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2622575,"date":"2023-10-31T12:17:33","date_gmt":"2023-10-31T19:17:33","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2622575"},"modified":"2023-10-31T14:50:30","modified_gmt":"2023-10-31T21:50:30","slug":"tesla-wins-fatal-autopilot-crash-jury-trial","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/31\/tesla-wins-fatal-autopilot-crash-jury-trial\/","title":{"rendered":"Tesla wins fatal Autopilot crash jury trial"},"content":{"rendered":" "speakable-summary\">A jury on Tuesday handed Tesla another win after siding with the automaker over allegations that its Autopilot advanced driver assistance system led to a death.<\/p>\n The case, which was being tried in the Superior Court of California, County of Riverside, was filed by two passengers who survived a 2019 crash and alleged that Tesla knew its product was defective. The two survivors sought $400 million in damages for the loss of the driver’s life, physical injury and mental anguish.<\/p>\n Tesla argued that the crash, which resulted in the death of the driver Micah Lee, was the result of human error \u2014 the same stance it’s taken in other Autopilot lawsuits.<\/p>\n While Tesla has won other lawsuits, including a California jury trial earlier this year that determined the automaker’s Autopilot system was not to blame for a 2019 crash. In that case, the "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/04\/21\/tesla-wins-autopilot-crash-case-in-california\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">jury awarded no damages<\/a> to Los Angeles resident Justine Hsu, who sued Tesla in 2020 alleging negligence, fraud and breach of contract. The Molander v. Tesla case that wrapped up Tuesday was the first jury trial involving a fatality.<\/p>\n Tesla still faces a number of other lawsuits in California, including a wrongful death suit that was filed by the family of Walter Huang, an Apple engineer who died after his Tesla Model X with Autopilot engaged crashed into a highway median. The State of California Department of Transportation is also named in the lawsuit. That wrongful death lawsuit, filed in California Superior Court, County of Santa Clara, alleges that errors by Tesla\u2019s Autopilot driver assistance system caused the crash that killed Huang on March 23, 2018. Huang, who was 38, died when his 2017 Tesla Model X hit a highway barrier on Highway 101 in Mountain View, California. A jury trial is expected to begin next year in that case.<\/p>\n Tesla is also facing scrutiny from "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/08\/29\/nhtsa-raises-more-concerns-about-teslas-autopilot-safety\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">federal and state regulators,<\/a> all of which are related to Autopilot and its upgraded version known as Full Self-Driving.<\/p>\n Tesla vehicles come standard with a driver-assistance system branded as Autopilot. For a $6,000 upgrade, owners can purchase Enhanced Autopilot, which includes several other features, including an active guidance system that navigates a car from a highway on-ramp to off-ramp, including interchanges and making lane changes.<\/p> "piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n For an\u00a0additional $12,000, owners can buy \u201cfull self-driving,\u201d or FSD \u2014 a feature that CEO\u00a0 "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/elon-musk\/\" data-mrf-link=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/elon-musk\/\">Elon Musk<\/a>\u00a0has promised for years will one day deliver full autonomous driving capabilities.<\/p>\n Tesla vehicles\u00a0 "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/05\/07\/tesla-refutes-elon-musks-timeline-on-full-self-driving\/\" data-mrf-link=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/05\/07\/tesla-refutes-elon-musks-timeline-on-full-self-driving\/\">are not self-driving<\/a>. Instead, FSD includes a number of automated driving features that still require the driver to be ready to take control at all times. It includes everything in Enhanced Autopilot and is supposed to handle steering on city streets and recognize and react to traffic lights and stop signs.<\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":" A jury on Tuesday handed Tesla another win after siding with the automaker over allegations that its Autopilot advanced driver assistance system led to a death. The case, which was being tried in the Superior Court of California, County of Riverside, was filed by two passengers who survived a 2019 crash and alleged that Tesla ","title":{"rendered":"So long, Twitter Circles"},"content":{"rendered":" "speakable-summary\">If tic-tac-toe has taught us anything, it’s that Xs and circles cannot peacefully coexist.<\/p>\n X, the app formerly known as Twitter, has shut down the Circles feature, which allowed users to post to a small, exclusive audience. Like an Instagram Close Friends story, Circles — n\u00e9e Twitter Circles — offered a more intimate social media experience. In other words, you could overshare about your life to an audience of friends only, rather than the whole internet. And isn’t one of the greatest joys of the internet to emotionally shitpost without worrying about the consequences?<\/p>\n But, as the whims of the Circle reminded us, nothing we say on the internet is ever actually free from consequence. The feature worked almost all of the time. Almost. And anything less than 100% efficacy is not ideal for a feature that people used to share private thoughts with trusted friends.<\/p>\n As early as February, some users reported that their Circle tweets were "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/02\/03\/twitter-circle-glitches-have-users-worried-about-privacy\/\">reaching a wider audience<\/a> than they were supposed to. These glitches showed up "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/04\/10\/twitter-circle-bug-not-private\/\">again in April<\/a>, and X (then known as Twitter) "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/05\/05\/twitter-confirms-circle-tweets-temporarily-were-not-private\/\">apologized<\/a> for the error in May, marking a rare moment of transparency for the company.<\/p>\n Even when Circle tweets were truly private, they often appeared not to be — the green banner denoting it as a Circle post only appeared some of the time (I had received some paranoid texts from friends who wondered if I knew I had posted about [redacted] on main, but nope, this was just the glitchy old bird app playing tricks on us).<\/p>\n "embed breakout embed-oembed embed--twitter\">\n "twitter-tweet\" data-width=\"550\" data-dnt=\"true\">\n "en\" dir=\"ltr\">I can't believe this website is going to take away my most treasured joke: my Twitter circle that only contains Tony Hawk.
"https:\/\/t.co\/P9pRF2HTIy\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">pic.twitter.com\/P9pRF2HTIy<\/a><\/p>\n — Giovanni Colantonio (@MarioPrime) "https:\/\/twitter.com\/MarioPrime\/status\/1719398305526861961?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">October 31, 2023<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote> "piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n "https:\/\/platform.twitter.com\/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"><\/script><\/div>\n But perhaps nothing is sadder than the loss of "https:\/\/twitter.com\/MarioPrime\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">one user<\/a>‘s “most treasured joke,” in which he posted to a Circle audience consisting only of Tony Hawk, because you could add people who didn’t follow you to your Circle. And they could not remove themselves.<\/p>\n Some users have expressed concern that their private musings would be made public, now that Circles are no longer. So far, this doesn’t seem to be the case, though you’re able to view your own Circle tweets on your profile. But on X, who knows when something will break, so if you have anything salacious up, it might be worth deleting.<\/p>\n It’s not clear why "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/09\/21\/x-is-shutting-down-its-circle-feature-in-october\/\">X is sunsetting Circles<\/a> — perhaps it will come back as a paid benefit, like another beloved feature, "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/08\/15\/x-formerly-twitter-makes-x-pro-formerly-tweetdeck-a-subscriber-only-product\/\">TweetDeck<\/a> (now called X Pro). But users will understandably be annoyed if they have to pay money to X to regain features they used to have for free.<\/p>\n "embed breakout embed-oembed embed--techcrunch\">\n "wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"i0QNe6bERD\"> "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/04\/10\/twitter-circle-bug-not-private\/\">Twitter Circle tweets are not that private anymore<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n ndered":"SBF\u2019s defense puts forth a 35-minute last-ditch effort to show his goodwill"},"content":{"rendered":" "speakable-summary\"> "featured__span-first-words\">As Sam Bankman-Fried<\/span> took the stand for the last time in his trial for fraud and money laundering, his main lawyer, Mark Cohen, returned to question him on a number of themes that prosecutors touched on in the past few days. But this time, he took a different approach, presenting the defendant as a person who was acting in good faith.<\/p>\n \u201cWe lived and died by having a better product than competitors,\u201d Bankman-Fried said of his "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/11\/11\/ftx-files-for-bankruptcy-ceo-sam-bankman-fried-steps-down\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">now-bankrupt crypto exchange<\/a>, FTX. Bankman-Fried owned majority stakes in both FTX and its sister trading firm, Alameda Research, but insisted he wanted the best for both.<\/p>\n Bankman-Fried has been "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/26\/sam-bankman-fried-takes-the-stand\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">testifying since Thursday afternoon<\/a>, and the prosecution has grilled him for the past few days as "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/30\/sam-bankman-fried-ftx-cross-examination\/\">part of their cross-examination<\/a>. On Tuesday, when the defense lawyers returned to reexamine him, he was swaying slightly on the stand, shoulders drawn down and forward. He spoke softly, but was more talkative than earlier in the day and on Monday when he was being questioned.<\/p>\n Contrary to the picture prosecutors tried to paint, Bankman-Fried insisted that he was not involved in the day-to-day trading operations of Alameda or its \u201ccore operations,\u201d but instead emphasized his concern for its leadership at the time, saying he wanted to be involved in many of its venture investments, decisions on hedging, and other areas.
"extra-crunch-offer-container\"><\/div>","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":" Contrary to the picture prosecutors tried to paint, Bankman-Fried insisted that he was not involved in the day-to-day trading operations of Alameda or its \u201ccore Reporter, Crypto, TC+","cbDescription":" Jacquelyn Melinek is a senior cryptocurrency reporter based in New York City. She previously was a crypto reporter for Blockworks covering decentralized finance, DAOs and crypto venture capital funding and prior to that covered energy markets for S&P Global Platts and Bloomberg News. Her articles are published in over 70 news outlets and she graduated from the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill with a degree in Media and Journalism and a minor in creative writing. Disclosure: Jacquelyn owns various cryptocurrencies including Bitcoin and Ethereum. She does not day trade cryptocurrencies, NFTs or any other crypto-related products. Link","children":[]},{"id":2593262,"order":6,"parent":0,"text":"Mastodon","url":"https:\/\/mstdn.social\/@TechCrunch","attr":"","target":"","classes":[""],"description":"","object_id":2593262,"object":"custom","type":"custom","type_label":"Custom Link","children":[]}]},"entities":{"posts":[{"id":2622542,"date":"2023-10-31T12:31:47","date_gmt":"2023-10-31T19:31:47","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2622542"},"modified":"2023-10-31T14:23:01","modified_gmt":"2023-10-31T21:23:01","slug":"log-analysis-and-security-firm-graylog-raises-9m-in-equity-30m-in-debt","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/31\/log-analysis-and-security-firm-graylog-raises-9m-in-equity-30m-in-debt\/","title":{"rendered":"Log analysis and security firm Graylog raises $9M in equity, $30M in debt"},"content":{"rendered":" "speakable-summary\">The decline in VC funding for cybersecurity startups might finally be reversing course after months of discouraging trend lines.<\/p>\n Recently, Crunchbase "https:\/\/news.crunchbase.com\/cybersecurity\/vc-funding-q3-bounce-back-2023\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">reported<\/a> that cybersecurity startups raised nearly $1.9 billion through 153 deals in Q3 — a 12% increase from the $1.7 billion raised across 181 deals in the previous quarter.<\/p>\n There’s anecdotal evidence of a turnaround, to be sure. Today, "https:\/\/graylog.org\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Graylog<\/a>, a Houston-based company that develops tools to help detect, analyze and respond to digital security threats, announced that it raised $39 million in a funding round co-led by Silver Lake Waterman, Piper Sandler Merchant Banking and Harbert Growth Partners.<\/p>\n That “$39 million” figure is a little misleading, however. Only $9 million of the tranche was equity — an extension of Graylog’s $18 million Series C round that closed in June 2021. The rest — $30 million — is in the form of what Graylog CEO Andy Grolnick is calling a “flex debt” facility.<\/p>\n “Given that Graylog is close to being cash-flow positive, the blend of equity and debt enables the company to continue its strong trajectory and bridge to profitability while minimizing dilution for investors and employees,” Grolnick said. “While Graylog is not disclosing valuation, the recent round represents a solid increase from the prior round.”<\/p>\n Graylog has its roots in an open source project launched in 2009 by Lennart Koopmann, a software engineer, who at the time was seeking to create a better way to manage and analyze machine log data. Koopmann eventually commercialized the open source project to found Graylog the company, which hired Grolnick as CEO in late 2020.<\/p>\n Graylog’s original product suite, which it still offers, focuses on collecting, storing and analyzing log data for IT troubleshooting and error detection. But through a combination of acquisitions and in-house R&D, the company recently branched into cybersecurity, rolling out products — Graylog API Security and Graylog Security — for API threat monitoring, security analytics, incident investigation and anomaly detection capabilities.<\/p> "piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n Grolnick claims that Graylog Security, launched in May 2022, now represents over 50% of Graylog’s net new customer sales.<\/p>\n “We’ve seen our business thrive lately as our value proposition has resonated with organizations looking for security solutions that are as effective in detecting threats as they are in managing costs,” Grolnick added. “This has allowed us to overcome some of the macro challenges facing tech companies over the last year.”<\/p>\n Graylog\u2019s competitors in the\u00a0 "https:\/\/www.marketsandmarkets.com\/Market-Reports\/log-management-market-66937877.html#:~:text=What%20is%20the%20market%20size,14.1%25%20during%20the%20forecast%20period.\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">over $4.1 billion log management segment<\/a> span Splunk, Elastic and Sumo Logic, as well as newer entrants like "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/09\/30\/coralogix-lands-25m-series-b-to-rethink-log-analysis-and-monitoring\/\">Coralogix<\/a>, "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/02\/14\/logz-io-bets-on-generative-ai-to-help-ops-teams-remediate-issues\/\">Logz.io<\/a> and CrowdStrike-owned "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/02\/18\/logging-startups-are-suddenly-hot-as-crowdstrike-nabs-humio-for-400m\/\">Humio<\/a>. But Grolnick asserts that Graylog has momentum on its side.<\/p>\n Graylog’s paid and open source tools now serve more than 200,000 users across over 50,000 installations, he says. And among the company’s client base are large defense customers like the U.S. Army, the U.S. Air Force, Lockheed Martin and SAIC.<\/p>\n Grolnick expects 110-employee Graylog, which saw new bookings grow 67% in Q3 year-over-year, to be cash-flow positive in the second half of 2024.<\/p>\n “The time was good to raise capital for a couple of reasons,” he said. “First, we wanted to take advantage of the opportunity to build market share in an environment where we were seeing our growth accelerate . . . Second, given our current trajectory, we had strong interest from both existing and new investors, which made the process relatively smooth. The new funds will be used to drive growth and bridge to profitability. With the new capital, key growth investments are being made in product development, global sales and channel expansion and customer success.”<\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":" The decline in VC funding for cybersecurity startups might finally be reversing course after months of discouraging trend lines. Recently, Crunchbase reported that cybersecurity startups raised nearly $1.9 billion through 153 deals in Q3 — a 12% increase from the $1.7 billion raised across 181 deals in the previous quarter. There’s anecdotal evidence of a latest-alphafold-model-is-more-useful-for-drug-discovery\/","title":{"rendered":"DeepMind’s latest AlphaFold model is more useful for drug discovery"},"content":{"rendered":" "speakable-summary\">Nearly five years ago, DeepMind, one of Google’s more prolific AI-centered research labs, debuted "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/alphafold\/\">AlphaFold<\/a>, an AI system that can accurately predict the structures of many proteins inside the human body. Since then, DeepMind has improved on the system, releasing an updated and more capable version of AlphaFold — "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/07\/22\/deepmind-puts-the-entire-human-proteome-online-as-folded-by-alphafold\/\">AlphaFold 2<\/a> — in 2020.<\/p>\n And the lab’s work continues.<\/p>\n Today, DeepMind revealed that the newest release of AlphaFold, the successor to AlphaFold 2, can generate predictions for nearly all molecules in the Protein Data Bank, the world’s largest open access database of biological molecules.<\/p>\n Already, "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/11\/04\/isomorphic-labs-is-alphabets-play-in-ai-drug-discovery\/#:~:text=The%20field%20of%20drug%20discovery,into%20a%20tractable%20information%20problem.\">Isomorphic Labs<\/a>, a spin-off of DeepMind focused on drug discovery, is applying the new AlphaFold model — which it co-designed — to therapeutic drug design, according to a "https:\/\/deepmind.google\/discover\/blog\/a-glimpse-of-the-next-generation-of-alphafold\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">post<\/a> on the DeepMind blog, helping to characterize different types of molecular structures important for treating disease.<\/p>\n New capabilities<\/h2>\n The new AlphaFold’s capabilities extend beyond protein prediction.<\/p>\n DeepMind claims that the model can also accurately predict the structures of ligands — molecules that bind to “receptor” proteins and cause changes in how cells communicate — as well as nucleic acids (molecules that contain key genetic information) and post-translational modifications (chemical changes that occur after a protein’s created).<\/p>\n "attachment_2622444\" style=\"width: 1034px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"> "caption-attachment-2622444\" decoding=\"async\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"size-full wp-image-2622444\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/unnamed.webp\" alt=\"A protein structure predicted by the latest AlphaFold model.\" width=\"1024\" height=\"675\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/unnamed.webp 1232w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/unnamed.webp?resize=150,99 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/unnamed.webp?resize=300,198 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/unnamed.webp?resize=768,506 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/unnamed.webp?resize=680,448 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/unnamed.webp?resize=1200,791 1200w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/unnamed.webp?resize=50,33 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px\" \/> "caption-attachment-2622444\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"> Image Credits:<\/strong> DeepMind<\/p><\/div><\/p> "piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n Predicting protein-ligand structures can be a useful tool in drug discovery, DeepMind notes, as it can help scientists identify and design new molecules that could become drugs.<\/p>\n Currently, pharmaceutical researchers use computer simulations known as “docking methods” to determine how proteins and ligands will interact. Docking methods require specifying a reference protein structure and a suggested position on that structure for the ligand to bind to.<\/p>\n With the latest AlphaFold, however, there’s no need to use a reference protein structure or suggested position. The model can predict proteins that haven’t been “structurally characterized” before, while at the same time simulating how proteins and nucleic acids interact with other molecules — a level of modeling that DeepMind says isn’t possible with today’s docking methods.<\/p>\n "4t9u1\">“Early analysis also shows that our model greatly outperforms [the previous generation of] AlphaFold on some protein structure prediction problems that are relevant for drug discovery, like antibody binding,” DeepMind writes in the post. “Our model\u2019s dramatic leap in performance shows the potential of AI to greatly enhance scientific understanding of the molecular machines that make up the human body.”<\/p>\n The newest AlphaFold isn’t perfect, though.<\/p>\n In a "https:\/\/storage.googleapis.com\/deepmind-media\/DeepMind.com\/Blog\/a-glimpse-of-the-next-generation-of-alphafold\/alphafold_latest_oct2023.pdf\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">whitepaper<\/a> detailing the system’s strengths and limitations, researchers at DeepMind and Isomorphic Labs reveal that the system falls short of the best-in-class method for predicting the structures of RNA molecules — the molecules in the body that carry the instructions for making proteins.<\/p>\n Doubtless, both DeepMind and Isomorphic Labs are working to address this.<\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":" Nearly five years ago, DeepMind, one of Google’s more prolific AI-centered research labs, debuted AlphaFold, an AI system that can accurately predict the structures of many proteins inside the human body. Since then, DeepMind has improved on the system, releasing an updated and more capable version of AlphaFold — AlphaFold 2 — in 2020. And […]<\/p>\n","protected":false},"author":133574536,"featured_media":2618210,"comment_status":"open","ping_status":"closed","sticky":false,"template":"","format":"standard","meta":{"amp_status":"","relegenceEntities":[],"relegenceSubjects":[],"carmot_uuid":"5df8d1e5-5d50-3d88-b8fb-8df1577c93b3","footnotes":"","apple_news_api_created_at":"2023-10-31T15:50:11Z","apple_news_api_id":"6932e75a-b78a-4afd-a351-e9d9ccf7f51d","apple_news_api_modified_at":"2023-10-31T17:54:15Z","apple_news_api_revision":"AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAA==","apple_news_api_share_url":"https:\/\/apple.news\/AaTLnWreKSv2jUenZzPf1HQ","apple_news_coverimage":0,"apple_news_coverimage_caption":"","apple_news_is_hidden":false,"apple_news_is_paid":false,"apple_news_is_preview":false,"apple_news_is_sponsored":false,"apple_news_maturity_rating":"","apple_news_metadata":"\"\"","apple_news_pullquote":"","apple_news_pullquote_position":"","apple_news_slug":"","apple_news_sections":"\"\"","apple_news_suppress_video_url":false,"apple_news_use_image_component":false},"categories":[577047203,577030454],"tags":[14067,210341831,576603353,449555745,1460,576945634],"crunchbase_tag":[],"tc_stories_tax":[],"tc_ec_category":[],"tc_event":[],"tc_regions_tax":[],"yoast_head":"\n name=search_term_string"}],"inLanguage":"en-US"},{"@type":"Organization","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#organization","name":"TechCrunch","alternateName":"TC","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/","logo":{"@type":"ImageObject","inLanguage":"en-US","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","contentUrl":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","width":1200,"height":1200,"caption":"TechCrunch"},"image":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/"},"sameAs":["https:\/\/www.facebook.com\/techcrunch","https:\/\/twitter.com\/TechCrunch","https:\/\/mstdn.social\/@TechCrunch","https:\/\/bsky.app\/profile\/techcrunch.bsky.social","https:\/\/www.threads.net\/@techcrunch"]}]}},"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/576945634"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=576945634"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_battlefield?tags=576945634"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=576945634"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_unified_video?tags=576945634"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=576945634"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2622181,"date":"2023-10-31T07:23:14","date_gmt":"2023-10-31T14:23:14","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2622181"},"modified":"2023-10-31T08:37:29","modified_gmt":"2023-10-31T15:37:29","slug":"new-nonprofit-backed-by-crypto-billionaire-scores-ai-chips-worth-500m","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/31\/new-nonprofit-backed-by-crypto-billionaire-scores-ai-chips-worth-500m\/","title":{"rendered":"New nonprofit backed by crypto billionaire scores AI chips worth $500M"},"content":{"rendered":" "speakable-summary\">It’s strange times we’re living in when a blockchain billionaire, not the usual Big Tech suspects, is the one supplying the compute capacity needed to develop generative AI.<\/p>\n It was revealed yesterday that Jed McCaleb, the co-founder of blockchain startups Stellar, Ripple and Mt Gox and aerospace company Vast, launched a 501(c)(3)\u00a0nonprofit that purchased 24,000 Nvidia H100 GPUs to build data centers that’ll lease capacity to AI projects.<\/p>\n Already, the cluster of GPUs — worth an estimated half a billion dollars and among the largest in the world — is being used by startups Imbue and Character.ai for AI model experimentation, claims Eric Park, the CEO of a newly formed organization, "https:\/\/voltagepark.com\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Voltage Park<\/a>, that’s charged with running and managing the data centers.<\/p>\n \u201cThe goal was to unlock access to startups, scale-ups and research organizations that are currently blocked from this space due to restrictive contracts, the scarcity of GPUs and high minimum purchase thresholds so that they can access the vital resources they need to innovate,” Park told TechCrunch in an email interview. “We\u2019re continuing to speak with folks in the industry to understand their needs and are using what we learn to inform how we build out our remaining clusters so that they\u2019re useful to as many customers as possible.”<\/p>\n Most companies training models, particularly generative AI models like\u00a0 "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/chatgpt\/\" data-mrf-link=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/chatgpt\/\">ChatGPT<\/a>\u00a0and\u00a0 "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/07\/26\/stability-ai-releases-its-latest-image-generating-model-stable-diffusion-xl-1-0\/\" data-mrf-link=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/07\/26\/stability-ai-releases-its-latest-image-generating-model-stable-diffusion-xl-1-0\/\">Stable Diffusion<\/a>, heavily rely on GPU-based hardware. GPUs’ ability to perform many computations in parallel make them well-suited to training — and serving — today\u2019s most capable AI.<\/p>\n But there aren’t enough chips to go around.<\/p>\n Microsoft is facing a shortage of the server hardware needed to run AI so severe that it might lead to service disruptions, the company\u00a0 "https:\/\/www.cnbc.com\/2023\/07\/28\/microsoft-annual-report-highlights-importance-of-gpus.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-mrf-link=\"https:\/\/www.cnbc.com\/2023\/07\/28\/microsoft-annual-report-highlights-importance-of-gpus.html\">warned<\/a> in a summer earnings report. And some of Nvidia\u2019s best-performing AI cards are "https:\/\/www.barrons.com\/articles\/nvidia-ai-chips-coreweave-cloud-6db44825#:~:text=The%20rising%20excitement%20over%20generative,technology%20industry's%20most%20precious%20resource.\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-mrf-link=\"https:\/\/www.barrons.com\/articles\/nvidia-ai-chips-coreweave-cloud-6db44825#:~:text=The%20rising%20excitement%20over%20generative,technology%20industry's%20most%20precious%20resource.\">reportedly<\/a>\u00a0sold out until 2024.<\/p> "piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n “The shortage for cutting-edge compute is dire,” Park said. “I have conversations with companies of all sizes — startups, scale-ups and big labs — and pretty much every single one tells me they can\u2019t get enough H100s to train their models. There\u2019s a compounding difficulty for startups and scale-ups who can\u2019t sign the large contracts many clouds require to access these chips, and that\u2019s really limiting AI innovation.”<\/p>\n Voltage Park was established under a somewhat unusual structure.<\/p>\n McCaleb started a nonprofit called the Navigation Fund to whose endowment he donated. The Navigation Fund then purchased the aforementioned H100s — paying “full sales and use taxes,” despite the Navigation Fund’s ostensible nonprofit status — and transferred ownership of the GPUs to for-profit<\/em> Voltage Park, which is technically a subsidiary of the Navigation Fund.<\/p>\n “Navigation\u2019s board determined that a for-profit subsidiary would be better able to set up specialized operations to manage a cluster of this scale,” a Navigation Fund spokesperson told TechCrunch in an email. “They created Voltage Park to do that, and transferred ownership of the GPUs as part of the initial capital contribution. There was good strategic reason for doing this. A subsidiary would be better placed to pursue the market opportunity around cutting-edge compute, while the Navigation Fund would be able to focus exclusively on its mission and charitable grant-making.”<\/p>\n The spokesperson went on to say that McCaleb doesn’t own, run or earn profits from the Brooklyn, New York-based Navigation Fund or Voltage Park, which are run by separate executive teams and have independent boards of directors. Presumably, there’s a considerable tax benefit to McCaleb’s donation — even if the nonprofit recipient immediately re-gifted the assets to Voltage Park.<\/p>\n Voltage Park won’t be the Navigation Fund’s only project. The spokesperson described it as a “long-term” nonprofit foundation with interests in a range of sectors, including farmed animal welfare, criminal justice reform, open science, climate and AI safety, that’ll support “organizations, activists, advocates and entrepreneurs.”<\/p>\n The Navigation Fund’s got a ways to go before it embarks on any of those endeavors, though. It doesn’t appear to be formally registered as a nonprofit yet; when TechCrunch consulted an expert last week to perform a search for the Navigation Fund on two industry-standard databases, Charity Navigator and GuideStar, the expert couldn’t find a listing. And the Navigation Fund’s president, David Coman-Hidy, only joined in August.<\/p>\n That’s not to suggest impropriety. The Navigation Fund might well have its paperwork in order and filed, but the IRS simply hasn’t gotten around to processing it yet.<\/p>\n Whatever the Navigation Fund’s tax status, a percentage of Voltage Park\u2019s profits will go to the Navigation Fund to support its philanthropic mission, the spokesperson said.<\/p>\n Voltage Park’s full cluster isn’t online. But once it is closer to the end of the year (assuming all goes according to plan), it’ll be live across three states — Texas, Virginia and Washington. Park says that a “significant portion” will be reserved for early-stage startups and developers and that capacity will be available both for short-term leases and hourly billing.<\/p>\n \u201cWe set up Voltage Park to help ensure a broad range of companies have a seat at the [AI] table,” Park said. “We currently offer bare-metal machine learning training infrastructure, but our mission is broader — we want to make machine learning accessible to a wider audience by lowering the barrier to entry. This may include additional services built on top of our infrastructure. We\u2019re still in the early days of this industry and we\u2019ll adapt as the field develops and matures.\u201d<\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":" It’s strange times we’re living in when a blockchain billionaire, not the usual Big Tech suspects, is the one supplying the compute capacity needed to develop generative AI. It was revealed yesterday that Jed McCaleb, the co-founder of blockchain startups Stellar, Ripple and Mt Gox and aerospace company Vast, launched a 501(c)(3)\u00a0nonprofit that purchased 24,000 […]<\/p>\n","protected":false},"author":133574536,"featured_media":2621912,"comment_status":"open","ping_status":"closed","sticky":false,"template":"","format":"standard","meta":{"amp_status":"","relegenceEntities":[],"relegenceSubjects":[],"carmot_uuid":"134a3c82-97be-341f-8cf9-59ede8c1b800","footnotes":"","apple_news_api_created_at":"2023-10-31T14:23:23Z","apple_news_api_id":"30f05ca1-4d45-4450-a7cc-aea3f5fbfea9","apple_news_api_modified_at":"2023-10-31T15:37:21Z","apple_news_api_revision":"AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAA==","apple_news_api_share_url":"https:\/\/apple.news\/AMPBcoU1FRFCnzK6j9fv-qQ","apple_news_coverimage":0,"apple_news_coverimage_caption":"","apple_news_is_hidden":false,"apple_news_is_paid":false,"apple_news_is_preview":false,"apple_news_is_sponsored":false,"apple_news_maturity_rating":"","apple_news_metadata":"\"\"","apple_news_pullquote":"","apple_news_pullquote_position":"","apple_news_slug":"","apple_news_sections":"\"\"","apple_news_suppress_video_url":false,"apple_news_use_image_component":false},"categories":[577047203,20429],"tags":[14067,64575263,5324,576717904,212927858,6917,4621],"crunchbase_tag":[],"tc_stories_tax":[],"tc_ec_category":[],"tc_event":[],"tc_regions_tax":[],"yoast_head":"\n Park Mansion"},{"@type":"WebSite","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#website","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/","name":"TechCrunch","description":"Startup and Technology News","publisher":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#organization"},"alternateName":"TC","potentialAction":[{"@type":"SearchAction","target":{"@type":"EntryPoint","urlTemplate":"https:\/\/search.techcrunch.com\/search?p={search_term_string}"},"query-input":"required name=search_term_string"}],"inLanguage":"en-US"},{"@type":"Organization","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#organization","name":"TechCrunch","alternateName":"TC","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/","logo":{"@type":"ImageObject","inLanguage":"en-US","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","contentUrl":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","width":1200,"height":1200,"caption":"TechCrunch"},"image":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/"},"sameAs":["https:\/\/www.facebook.com\/techcrunch","https:\/\/twitter.com\/TechCrunch","https:\/\/mstdn.social\/@TechCrunch","https:\/\/bsky.app\/profile\/techcrunch.bsky.social","https:\/\/www.threads.net\/@techcrunch"]}]}},"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/4621"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=4621"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_battlefield?tags=4621"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=4621"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_unified_video?tags=4621"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=4621"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2619562,"date":"2023-10-31T07:00:37","date_gmt":"2023-10-31T14:00:37","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2619562"},"modified":"2023-10-31T09:13:57","modified_gmt":"2023-10-31T16:13:57","slug":"connectly-taps-automation-to-nudge-shoppers-to-complete-purchases","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/31\/connectly-taps-automation-to-nudge-shoppers-to-complete-purchases\/","title":{"rendered":"Connectly taps automation to nudge shoppers to complete purchases"},"content":{"rendered":" "speakable-summary\">Most consumers interact with e-commerce brands through social media, text and email. Brands reach out with promotions and discounts. But the engagement and read rates tend to be low; "https:\/\/www.gartner.com\/en\/newsroom\/press-releases\/2019-03-11-gartner-survey-shows-brands-risk-losing-38-percent-of\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">according<\/a> to Gartner, brands risk losing 38% of customers due to poor marketing personalization efforts.<\/p>\n Stefanos Loukakos, the former head of Meta’s "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2019\/08\/29\/facebook-rolls-out-new-business-tools-for-messenger-kills-the-discover-tab\/\">business-focused Messenger<\/a> division, thought the solution might lie in algorithms to drive marketing at the right time — and to the right person.<\/p>\n To test this theory, Loukakos founded "https:\/\/www.connectly.ai\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Connectly<\/a>, which hosts a platform for businesses to create messaging campaigns and automate conversations with customers across messaging apps. Connectly today announced that it raised $7.85 million in a Series A round led by Volpe Capital with participation from RX Ventures and DST Global, bringing the startup’s total raised to $17.25 million.<\/p>\n Loukakos launched Connectly in 2020 alongside Yandong Liu, previously a lead engineer on Uber’s machine learning team, whom he met through a mutual friend in the founder community.<\/p>\n Using Connectly, brands can create campaigns and chatbots to automate text message conversations with customers. Loukakos pitches it as a way for brands to capture customers that’d otherwise potentially fall through the cracks.<\/p>\n "attachment_2619633\" style=\"width: 710px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"> "caption-attachment-2619633\" decoding=\"async\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"size-full wp-image-2619633\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/625dad863958c2001823ef3c.webp\" alt=\"Connectly\" width=\"700\" height=\"394\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/625dad863958c2001823ef3c.webp 700w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/625dad863958c2001823ef3c.webp?resize=150,84 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/625dad863958c2001823ef3c.webp?resize=300,169 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/625dad863958c2001823ef3c.webp?resize=680,383 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/625dad863958c2001823ef3c.webp?resize=50,28 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 700px) 100vw, 700px\" \/> "caption-attachment-2619633\" class=\"wp-caption-text\">The Connectly platform in action, from a customer perspective.
Image Credits:<\/strong> Connectly<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n “Connectly can tailor suggestions to ensure customers discover products they’ll love, as well as help companies gain a deeper understanding of their customers,” Loukakos said. “While traditional automation players focus on one-way messages, Connectly specializes in conversations with current and potential buyers — enabling outbound and inbound solutions.”<\/p> "piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n For example, if a customer abandons a cart on a brand’s website, Connectly can detect this and then send them a message asking why they didn’t make a purchase, Loukakos says. If the customer is “high value,” Connectly can offer to extend them a discount or lower-cost shipping.<\/p>\n On the back end, Connectly’s AI attempts to figure out which products customers are most interested in and build audience segments, which it displays to brands in a unified dashboard.<\/p>\n “Connectly provides a real-time pane of glass that connects the dots between messages and sales,” Loukakos said. “Connectly\u2019s AI uses natural language processing to understand what customers are saying and give them accurate recommendations on how to improve … [it also] uses machine learning to interpret and prioritize inbound messages, tagging in the appropriate agents and tasks so they know what actions to take.”<\/p>\n The stakes are high to get it right. According to one recent "https:\/\/www.performancemarketingworld.com\/article\/1814832\/almost-half-consumers-annoyed-constant-sms-marketing-brands\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">survey<\/a> of around 1,200 SMS users, nearly half reported being “annoyed” by text message marketing, with 28% saying that they’d abandoned at least one brand out of irritation.<\/p>\n Connectly appears to have had some success, though, with a customer base hovering around 200 brands and annual recurring revenue just eclipsing $1 million.<\/p>\n Despite competition from incumbents like Twilio and startups such as MessageBird and Attentive, the company is well-positioned for growth, Loukakos asserts, with plans to grow headcount from 35 employees to close to 40 by year-end 2023.<\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":" Most consumers interact with e-commerce brands through social media, text and email. Brands reach out with promotions and discounts. But the engagement and read rates tend to be low; according to Gartner, brands risk losing 38% of customers due to poor marketing personalization efforts. Stefanos Loukakos, the former head of Meta’s business-focused Messenger division, thought sign on building"},{"@type":"WebSite","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#website","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/","name":"TechCrunch","description":"Startup and Technology News","publisher":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#organization"},"alternateName":"TC","potentialAction":[{"@type":"SearchAction","target":{"@type":"EntryPoint","urlTemplate":"https:\/\/search.techcrunch.com\/search?p={search_term_string}"},"query-input":"required name=search_term_string"}],"inLanguage":"en-US"},{"@type":"Organization","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#organization","name":"TechCrunch","alternateName":"TC","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/","logo":{"@type":"ImageObject","inLanguage":"en-US","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","contentUrl":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","width":1200,"height":1200,"caption":"TechCrunch"},"image":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/"},"sameAs":["https:\/\/www.facebook.com\/techcrunch","https:\/\/twitter.com\/TechCrunch","https:\/\/mstdn.social\/@TechCrunch","https:\/\/bsky.app\/profile\/techcrunch.bsky.social","https:\/\/www.threads.net\/@techcrunch"]}]}},"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/4621"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=4621"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_battlefield?tags=4621"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=4621"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_unified_video?tags=4621"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=4621"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2620132,"date":"2023-10-31T05:00:33","date_gmt":"2023-10-31T12:00:33","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2620132"},"modified":"2023-10-31T10:32:32","modified_gmt":"2023-10-31T17:32:32","slug":"yuzu-wants-to-make-health-plans-cheaper-by-letting-insurers-mix-and-match-benefits","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/31\/yuzu-wants-to-make-health-plans-cheaper-by-letting-insurers-mix-and-match-benefits\/","title":{"rendered":"Yuzu wants to make health plans cheaper by letting insurers mix and match benefits"},"content":{"rendered":" "speakable-summary\">In the U.S., figuring out ways to pay for health insurance is a perennial problem — not just for individuals, but for the businesses employing them. Companies "https:\/\/www.kff.org\/health-costs\/report\/2022-employer-health-benefits-survey\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">pay<\/a> upwards of $22,000 per employee for family coverage, according to health policy publication KFF. And that’ll soon increase — the "https:\/\/www.ifebp.org\/store\/Pages\/health-care-costs-report-2024.aspx\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">cost<\/a> of medical plans is set to rise 7% next year.<\/p>\n Under the Affordable Care Act, businesses with 50 or more full-time employees must offer health coverage to 95% of their staff — or face penalties. But most smaller firms forgo offering benefits to cut costs. According to one recent "https:\/\/www.benefitspro.com\/2023\/04\/03\/crushed-by-rising-health-care-costs-small-businesses-urging-congress-to-act\/?slreturn=20230925213654\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">survey<\/a>, 61% of companies with 29 or fewer employees don’t offer any form of health insurance.<\/p>\n Entrepreneurs Russell Pekala, Ryan Lee and Max Kauderer — who’d experienced firsthand being overbilled for subpar care — thought there must be a better way. So they founded "https:\/\/yuzu.health\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Yuzu Health<\/a>, a startup that aims to help small businesses offer more affordable health plans by customizing plans based on their staffers’ needs.<\/p>\n Kauderer previously worked at Bain as a consultant, focusing primarily on healthcare clients. Pekala\u00a0was an early engineer at "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/donotpay\/\">DoNotPay<\/a>, the “robo-lawyer” service, while Lee\u00a0was formerly a product engineer at fintech "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/05\/20\/privacy-com-rebrands-to-lithic-raises-43m-for-virtual-payment-cards\/\">Lithic<\/a>.<\/p>\n Initially, Pekala, Lee and Kauderer set out to launch a service that’d help patients fight crippling medical debt. But as they dug into the U.S.’ healthcare affordability problem, they came to believe that tackling the equation from the insurance side would have a bigger impact.<\/p>\n “It feels like, more often than not, it\u2019s the insurance companies — not the healthcare providers — that are making decisions about a consumer\u2019s healthcare,” Kauderer told TechCrunch via email. “Insurance companies are the ones that are making decisions about how the cost of healthcare should be split among members and the collective group, how much freedom a member has to find a provider, what services are preventative or a necessity and so on.”<\/p>\n Kauderer describes Yuzu Health as a “nervous system” (anatomical reference intended, surely) for health insurance — a central platform that “plugs into” various parts of a health plan customized to an employer’s personnel. Insurance companies and brokers sponsor Yuzu to offer and administer self-funded plans to small businesses and startups, tracking claims and payments from patients, health providers and pharmacies.<\/p> "piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n Self-funded plans — plans where an employer pays member claims directly to healthcare providers — aren’t exceptionally common among small businesses. As of 2010, "https:\/\/www.commonwealthfund.org\/publications\/newsletter-article\/can-smaller-firms-self-fund-surprise-many-already-are\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">only<\/a> 16% of employees working for startups with three to 199 employees were covered by self-funded plans compared to 93% of employees working for companies with more than 5,000 employees.<\/p>\n One reason small businesses tend to shy away from self-funded plans is the risk associated with them. Self-funded plans don’t have pre-established costs, making it difficult for companies to plan and budget healthcare year over year. And unexpected high-cost claims through self-funded plans can affect a business’ cash flow, straining finances.<\/p>\n Yuzu attempts to mitigate this risk by allowing customers to design “nontraditional” health plans. For example, a broker using Yuzu can choose a flat, per-member-per-month-fee plan design where the copays change depending on the provider, or work with a preferred vendor for pharmacy benefits and virtual care.<\/p>\n "attachment_2620695\" style=\"width: 1034px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"> "caption-attachment-2620695\" decoding=\"async\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"size-full wp-image-2620695\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/hero_video.webp\" alt=\"Yuzu Health\" width=\"1024\" height=\"577\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/hero_video.webp 1686w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/hero_video.webp?resize=150,85 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/hero_video.webp?resize=300,169 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/hero_video.webp?resize=768,433 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/hero_video.webp?resize=680,383 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/hero_video.webp?resize=1536,865 1536w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/hero_video.webp?resize=1200,676 1200w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/hero_video.webp?resize=50,28 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px\" \/> "caption-attachment-2620695\" class=\"wp-caption-text\">Yuzu Health can build dashboards similar to these for its customers, relying on its in-house tech team.
Image Credits:<\/strong> Yuzu Health<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n “We\u2019re working with around ten health plans — created by insurance companies, brokers and plan sponsors — that service tens of thousands of employers on their end,” Kauderer said. “Some of these plan designs include direct primary care, cash pay models and financial assistance programs.”<\/p>\n In addition to delivering real-time reporting and alerts to customers, Yuzu handles provider payments and manages claims using large language models along the lines of "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/chatgpt\/\">ChatGPT<\/a>. “AI-assisted” support tools analyze plan documents to offer personalized provider and care recommendations, making members aware of potential treatment costs and suggesting alternatives where appropriate.<\/p>\n Kauderer explained: “A member might call in and want to get a better understanding of what a procedure might cost with their current plan … Yuzu automates all of this with AI, and provides the patient with a real-time, accurate response on care costs — and can even steer the patient to specific local providers that are more affordable and have better care outcomes.”<\/p>\n I’m skeptical that Yuzu’s AI is perfect — large language models have well-known "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/17\/microsoft-affiliated-research-finds-flaws-in-gtp-4\/\">flaws<\/a>, after all. And part of me wonders if enabling customers to pick and choose which benefits they provide might lead to inadequate or incomplete coverage for some employees.<\/p>\n Coverage gaps already exist. A 2022 "https:\/\/www.apa.org\/pubs\/reports\/work-in-america\/2023-workplace-health-well-being\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">survey<\/a> from the American Psychological Association found that only 43% of workers receive health insurance with coverage for mental health and substance abuse disorders. Could Yuzu’s business model exacerbate this?<\/p>\n Kauderer takes the position that lower-cost coverage — even if it isn’t comprehensive — is better than no coverage at all. He pointed to a "https:\/\/www.benefitspro.com\/2023\/04\/18\/hr-benefits-strategies-that-make-you-a-better-employer\/#:~:text=Nearly%2078%25%20of%20employees%20say,on%20employee%20retention%20and%20productivity.\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">recent<\/a> poll suggesting that 78% of employees would be more likely to stay in their current role if they had better health benefits — or benefits period.<\/p>\n “With Yuzu, small businesses and startups can save 40% or more savings on customizing top-tier benefits for their employees,” he said. “They don\u2019t need to sacrifice taking care of their employees and save money while doing so.”<\/p>\n In any case, NYC-based Yuzu sees its primary competitors as incumbent players like UnitedHealthcare, Humana and Aetna. The company is pre-release, but it’s raised $5 million in seed funding led by Lachy Groom with participation from Neo, Day One Ventures, Altman Capital, WndrCo and Browder Capital.<\/p>\n The proceeds are being put toward hiring (Yuzu has a five-person team), general growth and building new products, including cost containment and pricing transparency tools, Kauderer says.<\/p>\n “We\u2019re focused on developing our healthcare operating system, signing on more customers and providing accessible healthcare to more employers and employees,” he added. “We\u2019re helping small businesses and startups provide high-quality health insurance without overpaying.”<\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":" In the U.S., figuring out ways to pay for health insurance is a perennial problem — not just for individuals, but for the businesses employing them. Companies pay upwards of $22,000 per employee for family coverage, according to health policy publication KFF. And that’ll soon increase — the cost of medical plans is set to
