sign on building"},{"@type":"WebSite","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#website","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/","name":"TechCrunch","description":"Startup and Technology News","publisher":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#organization"},"alternateName":"TC","potentialAction":[{"@type":"SearchAction","target":{"@type":"EntryPoint","urlTemplate":"https:\/\/search.techcrunch.com\/search?p={search_term_string}"},"query-input":"required name=search_term_string"}],"inLanguage":"en-US"},{"@type":"Organization","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#organization","name":"TechCrunch","alternateName":"TC","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/","logo":{"@type":"ImageObject","inLanguage":"en-US","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","contentUrl":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","width":1200,"height":1200,"caption":"TechCrunch"},"image":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/"},"sameAs":["https:\/\/www.facebook.com\/techcrunch","https:\/\/twitter.com\/TechCrunch","https:\/\/mstdn.social\/@TechCrunch","https:\/\/bsky.app\/profile\/techcrunch.bsky.social","https:\/\/www.threads.net\/@techcrunch"]}]}},"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/577202278"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=577202278"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_battlefield?tags=577202278"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=577202278"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_unified_video?tags=577202278"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=577202278"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2618147,"date":"2023-10-31T04:00:26","date_gmt":"2023-10-31T11:00:26","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2618147"},"modified":"2023-10-31T10:46:42","modified_gmt":"2023-10-31T17:46:42","slug":"guiddes-ai-automatically-generates-documentation-videos-for-software","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/31\/guiddes-ai-automatically-generates-documentation-videos-for-software\/","title":{"rendered":"Guidde’s AI automatically generates software documentation videos"},"content":{"rendered":" "speakable-summary\">Organizations today rely on a growing number of apps to get work done.
"https:\/\/www.statista.com\/statistics\/1233538\/average-number-saas-apps-yearly\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">According<\/a> to Statista, in 2022, companies were licensing an average of 130 software-as-a-service (SaaS) apps, up from just eight in 2015.<\/p>\n What that means for employees, generally, is more work — more work getting up to speed with the various tools, reading documentation and completing tutorials, and even prepping for certifications, in some cases. A recent "https:\/\/www.ciodive.com\/news\/app-switching-enterprise-asana-report\/594233\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">poll<\/a> from Okta, the IT services management company, suggests that “app overload” is a top productivity blocker, with 26% of employees responding to the survey saying that it makes them less efficient at work.<\/p>\n A partial solution, believes Yoav Einav, a Belmont-based entrepreneur, is a tool that lets users create visual documentation — videos, mainly — for software onboarding. Einav is the co-founder and CEO of "http:\/\/guidde.com\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Guidde<\/a>, which leverages generative AI to automatically create embeddable video clips that instruct on how to use different web-based software apps.<\/p>\n "attachment_2618300\" style=\"width: 650px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"> "caption-attachment-2618300\" decoding=\"async\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"size-full wp-image-2618300\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/unnamed-3.jpg\" alt=\"Guidde\" width=\"640\" height=\"400\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/unnamed-3.jpg 640w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/unnamed-3.jpg?resize=150,94 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/unnamed-3.jpg?resize=300,188 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/unnamed-3.jpg?resize=50,31 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 640px) 100vw, 640px\" \/> "caption-attachment-2618300\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"> Image Credits:<\/strong> Guidde<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n Einav founded Guidde in 2020 alongside Dan Sahar. Both previously led product teams in data, machine learning operations and cybersecurity at companies like Qwilt, an open edge cloud startup, and Iguazio, a data management and orchestration platform.<\/p>\n “Guidde was founded in order to address a glaring gap Sahar and I experienced, which is how to enable users to be productive and drive engagement in business-to-business applications,” Einav told TechCrunch in an email interview. “This was exacerbated as companies shifted to more hybrid and remote work, causing onboarding and training to be severely hampered.”<\/p>\n Guidde works by capturing a user’s in-app activity through a Chrome extension, then transforming the recording using AI, automation and contextual analysis to create a video with an “AI-generated storyline,” as Einav describes it. Guidde-created videos can optionally feature an AI-generated voice in a desired language, background music and tags (which the platform automatically generate) that highlight key parts of a software workflow.<\/p> "piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n "il\">“Video<\/span> creation today is fragmented, lengthy and challenging — it typically involves multiple tools, multiple people and entails sometimes weeks of work to produce even a single "il\">video,” Einav said. “Guidde fuses multiple point-products with the power of AI to establish a single platform that allows anyone in an organization to create, edit, publish and analyze video and documentation for any software in minutes.”<\/span><\/p>\n I was a little skeptical of Guidde’s claims, I must say, given generative AI’s tendency to fail at even the most basic "https:\/\/richmond.com\/zzstyling\/column\/the-experiment-failed-ai-isn-t-ready-to-be-a-good-document-summarizer\/article_2e172e64-3d05-11ee-bfa6-c7394a2caabb.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">use cases<\/a>. But in my brief testing, the platform delivered on its promises, more or less.<\/p>\n Once the requisite Chrome extension installs, you can begin recording the process or workflow you wish to capture for a documentation video. Ingesting the finished recording, Guidde automatically splits it into labeled chapters — each with a description — based on actions taken during the recording, like button presses and browser tab switches, and generates an intro and outro voiceover.<\/p>\n "embed-youtube embed--youtube embed embed-jetpack breakout embed--video\" style=\"text-align:center; display: block;\"> "youtube-player embed-iframe embed-iframe--youtube\" width=\"640\" height=\"360\" src=\"https:\/\/www.youtube.com\/embed\/XXw_wRb66gQ?version=3&rel=1&showsearch=0&showinfo=1&iv_load_policy=1&fs=1&hl=en-US&autohide=2&wmode=transparent\" allowfullscreen=\"true\" style=\"border:0;\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts allow-same-origin allow-popups allow-presentation\"><\/iframe><\/span><\/p>\n Were I in the business of crafting a lot of SaaS tutorials, I could see myself using Guidde regularly — at least as a starting point. The AI isn’t perfect, but fortunately, any generated labels and descriptions can be edited before a video’s published.<\/p>\n Guidde also offers a streamlined video editing suite with effects like motion transitions, frame timing adjustment and cropping. If the platform’s synthetic voice options don’t suit a customer’s fancy, they can record their own to pair with the instructions in the video.<\/p>\n “We believe that we’ve found a nascent sweet spot at the intersection between PowerPoint and Loom that combines the simplicity of presentations and the engagement of video, so we appeal to the majority of enterprises where PowerPoint is a daily tool they\u2019ve used for years but async video still isn’t heavily used,” "il\">Einav said. “<\/span>Many teams that use Guidde often replace legacy desktop tools such as Camtasia, which they use for technical video production.”<\/p>\n Now, Guidde might not be able to convince\u00a0 every\u00a0<\/em>prospective corporate customer that its video creation platform, which is priced at $35 per user per month for medium-to-large-sized teams, is a worthwhile investment.
"https:\/\/research.com\/education\/video-training-statistics\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">According<\/a> to a 2019 Kultura survey, 67% of employees admit to not giving in-house training videos their full attention, instead skimming the videos or listening to them while doing something else.<\/p>\n On the other hand, perhaps that’s Guidde’s selling point<\/em>. If staffers aren’t watching videos that closely, why should employers spend a lot of time, energy and money producing them?<\/p>\n “We’ve held hundreds of conversations with employees across organizations large and small over the past two years,” "il\">Einav said. “Time and time again we heard the same issues:\u00a0<\/span>Many people hate recording their own voice and aren’t skilled at it … subject-matter experts often aren’t the ones creating content … [and] content lacks consistency and finish since each person uses a different look and feel, environment, voice and so on … We dove into the issues they faced today [and tried to solve them].”<\/p>\n "attachment_2618301\" style=\"width: 1034px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"> "caption-attachment-2618301\" decoding=\"async\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"size-full wp-image-2618301\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/maxresdefault-5.jpg\" alt=\"Guidde\" width=\"1024\" height=\"576\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/maxresdefault-5.jpg 1280w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/maxresdefault-5.jpg?resize=150,84 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/maxresdefault-5.jpg?resize=300,169 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/maxresdefault-5.jpg?resize=768,432 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/maxresdefault-5.jpg?resize=680,383 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/maxresdefault-5.jpg?resize=1200,675 1200w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/maxresdefault-5.jpg?resize=50,28 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px\" \/> "caption-attachment-2618301\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"> Image Credits:<\/strong> Guidde<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n Guidde appears to have gained a following, with a customer base that stands around 500 brands — including Payoneer, Redis and LiveNation — with “tens of thousands” of users combined. Revenue grew by more than 500% between last year and this year, meanwhile, "il\">Einav claims.<\/span><\/p>\n VCs see potential. Guidde today announced that it raised $11.6 million in a Series A funding round led by Norwest Venture Partners with participation from Entree Capital, Honeystone Ventures, Crescendo Ventures and Tiferes Ventures, bringing the company’s total raised to $15.6 million.<\/p>\n Guidde plans to use the new capital to expand its engineering and data science departments while growing its go-to-market team, "il\">Einav says. The startup has 17 employees at present, and aims to nearly double that number by the end off 2024.\u00a0<\/span><\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":" Organizations today rely on a growing number of apps to get work done. According to Statista, in 2022, companies were licensing an average of 130 software-as-a-service (SaaS) apps, up from just eight in 2015. What that means for employees, generally, is more work — more work getting up to speed with the various tools, reading s:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/28\/cruise-ceases-robotaxi-operations-the-apple-watch-gets-a-new-feature-and-carta-tries-to-head-off-bad-press\/","title":{"rendered":"Cruise ceases robotaxi operations, the Apple Watch gets a new feature and Carta tries to head off bad press"},"content":{"rendered":" "speakable-summary\">Hello, ghouls and goblins, and welcome to this Halloween Weekend edition of Week in Review (WiR), TechCrunch’s weekly tech recap in newsletter form. For our U.S.-based readers (and this reporter), ’tis the time for mid-autumn merrymaking — time-tested traditions like jack-o’-lantern carving, costuming and apple picking. May we all make the most of it.<\/p>\n In this issue of WiR, we cover the California DMV suspending Cruise’s robotaxi permit, doing expenses in VR, the Apple Watch’s best new feature going live and an e-commerce startup founded by an ex-PayPal exec that aims to give customers more control over their shopping data. Elsewhere, we spotlight the victims of Okta’s latest hack, Carta’s CEO trying to head off bad press, the latest from the FTX trial and Rivian winning the longest off-road competition in the U.S.<\/p>\n It\u2019s a lot to get through, so let\u2019s not delay. But first, a reminder to "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/newsletters\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">sign up here<\/a>\u00a0to receive WiR in your inbox every Saturday if you haven\u2019t already done so.<\/p>\n Most read<\/h2>\n "speakable-summary\"> "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/24\/dmv-immediately-suspends-cruises-robotaxi-permit-in-california\/?mrfhud=true\"> Cruising no more:<\/strong><\/a> The California Department of Motor Vehicles on Tuesday suspended Cruise\u2019s deployment and driverless testing permits, ending the GM self-driving car subsidiary\u2019s robotaxi operations in San Francisco. Subsequently, Cruise announced that it would "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/26\/cruise-pauses-all-driverless-robotaxi-operations-to-rebuild-public-trust\/\">pause<\/a> all of its robotaxi operations, including in Austin, Houston, Phoenix and Miami, to “rebuild public trust.”<\/p>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/20\/i-did-my-expenses-in-vr-and-i-liked-it\/?mrfhud=true\">Expensing meets VR:<\/a><\/strong> Intrepid TC editor Darrell Etherington did his expensing in Concur using Meta’s latest headset, the Quest 3. So how’d it go? Concur “still sucks super hard in VR,” Darrell writes — but surprisingly, Concur didn’t suck any more than it does in more conventional computing environments, and he actually enjoyed doing most of the related, “normal computer” things on Quest 3.<\/p>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/25\/apple-watchs-best-new-feature-is-now-live\/?mrfhud=true\">Double tap that:<\/a>\u00a0<\/strong>With this week’s "https:\/\/www.apple.com\/newsroom\/2023\/10\/apple-watch-double-tap-gesture-now-available-with-watchos-10-1\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-mrf-link=\"https:\/\/www.apple.com\/newsroom\/2023\/10\/apple-watch-double-tap-gesture-now-available-with-watchos-10-1\/\">watchOS 10.1 drop<\/a>, Apple Watch Series 9 and Apple Watch Ultra 2 owners now have access to one of the smartwatches\u2019 more exciting features. Double Tap, which adds gesture-based interactions through tapping one\u2019s index finger and thumb together twice, is a clever new way to interact with the wearable when your other hand is full, Brian writes.<\/p>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/24\/new-e-commerce-startup-founded-by-an-ex-paypal-exec-gives-customers-control-of-their-own-shopping-data\/?mrfhud=true\"> Retail your way:<\/strong><\/a> Mary Ann writes about\u00a0 "https:\/\/www.nodemy.info\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-mrf-link=\"https:\/\/www.nodemy.info\/\">I Own My Data (IOMD)<\/a>, a startup founded by an ex-PayPal exec aiming to eliminate a tedious step for customers: creating an account every time you purchase something from an online store. With IOMD, all of a user\u2019s private information, such as past purchases, cards, addresses and preferences, are stored on their own device — so transactions can be completed instantly with a click, tap or touch anywhere on the web.<\/p> "piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/24\/oktas-latest-hack-fallout-hits-cloudflare-1password\/?mrfhud=true\"> Okta hack fallout:<\/strong><\/a> Network and security giant Cloudflare and password manager maker 1Password said hackers briefly targeted their systems following\u00a0 "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/20\/okta-says-hackers-stole-customer-access-tokens-from-support-unit\/\" data-mrf-link=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/20\/okta-says-hackers-stole-customer-access-tokens-from-support-unit\/\">a recent breach of Okta\u2019s support unit<\/a>. Both Cloudflare and 1Password said their intrusions were linked to the hack of Okta, the identity and access management platform, but that the incidents didn’t affect customer systems or user data.<\/p>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/25\/cartas-ceo-reaches-out-to-customers-about-bad-press-alerting-them-to-bad-press\/?mrfhud=true\">Carta fights back:<\/a> <\/strong>In an attempt at damage control, Henry Ward, the CEO of the equity management startup "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/carta\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-mrf-link=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/carta\/\">Carta<\/a>, this week emailed customers, telling them that if they’re concerned about “negative press” tied to the outfit, they should read a recent Medium post of his. In the "https:\/\/henrysward.medium.com\/what-i-tell-employees-about-negative-press-7c134e7a601c\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-mrf-link=\"https:\/\/henrysward.medium.com\/what-i-tell-employees-about-negative-press-7c134e7a601c\">post<\/a>, Ward outlines conversations he’s had with Carta employees about numerous stories surrounding the company, including stories about lawsuits around "https:\/\/fortune.com\/2023\/10\/16\/women-claims-mistreatment-carta-unicorn-startup\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">allegations of sexual abuse<\/a>\u00a0on the part of executives,\u00a0 "https:\/\/www.businessinsider.com\/carta-startup-discrimination-harassment-boys-club-allegations-henry-ward-lawsuit-2023-10\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-mrf-link=\"https:\/\/www.businessinsider.com\/carta-startup-discrimination-harassment-boys-club-allegations-henry-ward-lawsuit-2023-10\">a toxic “boy\u2019s club culture<\/a>” and indecent exposure, "https:\/\/sfstandard.com\/2023\/10\/25\/carta-san-francisco-lawsuits-insider-fortune-reports\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-mrf-link=\"https:\/\/sfstandard.com\/2023\/10\/25\/carta-san-francisco-lawsuits-insider-fortune-reports\/\">among other things<\/a>.<\/p>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/24\/ex-sdny-prosecutor-says-caroline-ellison-gary-wang-and-nishad-singh-probably-wont-get-jail-time\/\"> FTX execs likely escape jail:<\/strong><\/a> Gary Wang, co-founder and CTO of failed crypto exchange FTX; Caroline Ellison, CEO of Alameda, FTX’s sister company; and Nishad Singh, FTX head of engineering, have all pleaded guilty to charges after the exchange and Alameda’s dramatic downfall in November 2022. But an ex-Southern District of New York (SDNY) prosecutor, speaking to TechCrunch’s blockchain reporter Jacquelyn Melinek, says that Ellison, Wang and Singh probably won\u2019t get jail time, as they’ve been cooperating witnesses.<\/p>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/22\/rivian-r1t-is-the-first-ev-to-win-the-longest-off-road-competition-in-the-us\/?mrfhud=true\"> Rivian comes out ahead: <\/strong><\/a>In a win for Rivian, the Amazon-backed startup’s R1T is the first EV to win the longest off-road competition in the U.S., the Rebelle Rally. The race — now in its eighth year — requires teams to complete a 2,120-kilometer course using only paper maps, compasses and plotters, Kirsten writes.<\/p>\n Audio<\/h2>\n Looking for background listening material as you make costume alterations, paint pumpkins and restock the candy jar? TechCrunch has you covered — as always.<\/p>\n On "https:\/\/pod.link\/equity\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Equity<\/a><\/strong>, the crew covered a few deals of the week, including news from I Own My Data and AgentSync. Other big-ticket items included Carta’s comms snafu, the recent roadblock for Cruise driverless taxis (and why Waymo appears to be winning) and notes on Alphabet’s and Microsoft’s recent earnings.<\/p>\n "https:\/\/pod.link\/found\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Found<\/a><\/strong> spoke with Jonas Torland from 7Analytics, a Norwegian company that’s built a data platform that powers tools and products for sustainable risk management. Their models predict the paths of floodwaters, which allow them to predict and map the damage that results.<\/p>\n And "https:\/\/pod.link\/chainreaction\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Chain Reaction<\/a><\/strong> interviewed Josh Naftalis, partner at law firm Pallas Partners. Naftalis is a longtime attorney who represents companies, boards and executives in cases for white-collar criminal defense, regulatory enforcement matters, internal investigations, crisis management and more.<\/p>\n TechCrunch+<\/h2>\n TC+ subscribers get access to in-depth commentary, analysis and surveys — which you know if you\u2019re already a subscriber. If you\u2019re not, "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/subscribe\/?utm_medium=TCnewsletter&tpcc=TCdailynewsletter\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">consider signing up<\/a>. Here are a few highlights from this week:<\/em><\/p>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/26\/ai-will-make-spam-more-awful\/\">Spam gets worse:<\/a>\u00a0<\/strong>Haje writes about how AI-powered tools are making sales emails, phishing and spam worse for all of us — particularly tools that plug into social media to build a picture of what might be happening in their targets’ lives.<\/p>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/27\/big-tech-advertising-ai\/\">AI-boosted ads:<\/a>\u00a0<\/strong>Alex and Anna write that Big Tech firms with big reach have been raking in big ad bucks, lately — particularly those with AI chops, which has made their ability to pull in advertising dollars even stronger.<\/p>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/26\/why-are-seed-deals-expensive\/\"> Seed deals become pricey:<\/strong><\/a> Why are seed deals so expensive these days? Alex writes that rapid growth is to blame; late-stage deals are becoming rarer and<\/em>\u00a0smaller\u00a0 and\u00a0<\/em>cheaper today, conversely.<\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":" Hello, ghouls and goblins, and welcome to this Halloween Weekend edition of Week in Review (WiR), TechCrunch’s weekly tech recap in newsletter form. name=search_term_string\"}],\"inLanguage\":\"en-US\"},{\"@type\":\"Organization\",\"@id\":\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#organization\",\"name\":\"TechCrunch\",\"alternateName\":\"TC\",\"url\":\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/\",\"logo\":{\"@type\":\"ImageObject\",\"inLanguage\":\"en-US\",\"@id\":\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/\",\"url\":\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200\",\"contentUrl\":\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200\",\"width\":1200,\"height\":1200,\"caption\":\"TechCrunch\"},\"image\":{\"@id\":\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/\"},\"sameAs\":[\"https:\/\/www.facebook.com\/techcrunch\",\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/TechCrunch\",\"https:\/\/mstdn.social\/@TechCrunch\",\"https:\/\/bsky.app\/profile\/techcrunch.bsky.social\",\"https:\/\/www.threads.net\/@techcrunch\"]}]}<\/script>\n","yoast_head_json":{"title":"Week in Review | TechCrunch","description":"Read the latest news about Week in Review on TechCrunch","canonical":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/week-in-review\/","next":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/week-in-review\/page\/2\/","og_locale":"en_US","og_type":"article","og_title":"Week in Review | TechCrunch","og_description":"Read the latest news about Week in Review on TechCrunch","og_url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/week-in-review\/","og_site_name":"TechCrunch","og_image":[{"width":1200,"height":1200,"url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","type":"image\/png"}],"twitter_card":"summary_large_image","twitter_site":"@TechCrunch","schema":{"@context":"https:\/\/schema.org","@graph":[{"@type":"CollectionPage","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/week-in-review\/","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/week-in-review\/","name":"Week in Review | TechCrunch","isPartOf":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#website"},"primaryImageOfPage":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/week-in-review\/#primaryimage"},"image":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/week-in-review\/#primaryimage"},"thumbnailUrl":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/08\/GettyImages-1186172197.jpg","description":"Read the latest news about Week in Review on TechCrunch","inLanguage":"en-US"},{"@type":"ImageObject","inLanguage":"en-US","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/week-in-review\/#primaryimage","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/08\/GettyImages-1186172197.jpg","contentUrl":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/08\/GettyImages-1186172197.jpg","width":2309,"height":1299,"caption":"Network Security"},{"@type":"WebSite","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#website","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/","name":"TechCrunch","description":"Startup and Technology News","publisher":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#organization"},"alternateName":"TC","potentialAction":[{"@type":"SearchAction","target":{"@type":"EntryPoint","urlTemplate":"https:\/\/search.techcrunch.com\/search?p={search_term_string}"},"query-input":"required name=search_term_string"}],"inLanguage":"en-US"},{"@type":"Organization","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#organization","name":"TechCrunch","alternateName":"TC","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/","logo":{"@type":"ImageObject","inLanguage":"en-US","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","contentUrl":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","width":1200,"height":1200,"caption":"TechCrunch"},"image":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/"},"sameAs":["https:\/\/www.facebook.com\/techcrunch","https:\/\/twitter.com\/TechCrunch","https:\/\/mstdn.social\/@TechCrunch","https:\/\/bsky.app\/profile\/techcrunch.bsky.social","https:\/\/www.threads.net\/@techcrunch"]}]}},"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/36363"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=36363"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_battlefield?tags=36363"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=36363"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_unified_video?tags=36363"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=36363"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2620715,"date":"2023-10-27T07:10:08","date_gmt":"2023-10-27T14:10:08","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2620715"},"modified":"2023-10-27T09:16:11","modified_gmt":"2023-10-27T16:16:11","slug":"a-group-behind-stable-diffusion-wants-to-open-source-emotion-detecting-ai","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/27\/a-group-behind-stable-diffusion-wants-to-open-source-emotion-detecting-ai\/","title":{"rendered":"A group behind Stable Diffusion wants to open source emotion-detecting AI"},"content":{"rendered":" "speakable-summary\">In 2019, Amazon "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2019\/05\/23\/amazon-is-reportedly-working-on-an-emotion-tracking-alexa-wearable\/\">upgraded<\/a> its Alexa assistant with a feature that enabled it to detect when a customer was likely frustrated — and respond with proportionately more sympathy. If a customer asked Alexa to play a song and it queued up the wrong one, for example, and then the customer said “No, Alexa” in an upset tone, Alexa might apologize — and request a clarification.<\/p>\n Now, the group behind one of the data sets used to train the text-to-image model Stable Diffusion wants to bring similar emotion-detecting capabilities to every developer — at no cost.<\/p>\n This week, LAION, the nonprofit building image and text data sets for training generative AI, including Stable Diffusion, announced the "https:\/\/laion.ai\/blog\/open-empathic\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Open Empathic<\/a> project. Open Empathic aims to “equip open source AI systems with empathy and emotional intelligence,” in the group’s words.<\/p>\n “The LAION team, with backgrounds in healthcare, education and machine learning research, saw a gap in the open source community: emotional AI was largely overlooked,” Christoph Schuhmann, a LAION co-founder, told TechCrunch via email. “Much like our concerns about non-transparent AI monopolies that led to the birth of LAION, we felt a similar urgency here.”<\/p>\n Through Open Empathic, LAION is recruiting volunteers to submit audio clips to a database that can be used to create AI, including chatbots and text-to-speech models, that “understands” human emotions.<\/p>\n “With Open Empathic, our goal is to create an AI that goes beyond understanding just words,” Schuhmann added. “We aim for it to grasp the nuances in expressions and tone shifts, making human-AI interactions more authentic and empathetic.”<\/p>\n LAION, an acronym for “Large-scale Artificial Intelligence Open Network,” was founded in early 2021 by Schuhmann, who’s a German high school teacher by day, and several members of a Discord server for AI enthusiasts. Funded by donations and public research grants, including from AI startup "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/08\/24\/hugging-face-raises-235m-from-investors-including-salesforce-and-nvidia\/\">Hugging Face<\/a> and "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/10\/17\/stability-ai-the-startup-behind-stable-diffusion-raises-101m\/\">Stability AI<\/a>, the vendor behind Stable Diffusion, LAION’s stated mission is to democratize AI research and development resources — starting with training data.<\/p> "piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n “We’re driven by a clear mission: to harness the power of AI in ways that can genuinely benefit society,” Kari Noriy, an open source contributor to LAION and a PhD student at Bournemouth University, told TechCrunch via email. “We’re passionate about transparency and believe that the best way to shape AI is out in the open.”<\/p>\n Hence Open Empathic.<\/p>\n For the project’s initial phase, LAION has created a website that tasks volunteers with annotating YouTube clips — some pre-selected by the LAION team, others by volunteers — of an individual person speaking. For each clip, volunteers can fill out a detailed list of fields, including a transcription for the clip, an audio and video description and the person in the clip’s age, gender, accent (e.g. “British English”), arousal level (alertness — not<\/em> sexual, to be clear) and valence level (“pleasantness” versus “unpleasantness”).<\/p>\n Other fields in the form pertain to the clip’s audio quality and the presence (or absence) of loud background noises. But the bulk focus is on the person’s emotions — or at least, the emotions that volunteers perceive them to have.<\/p>\n From an array of drop-down menus, volunteers can select individual — or multiple — emotions ranging from “chirpy,” “brisk” and “beguiling” to “reflective” and “engaging.” Noriy says that the idea was to solicit “rich” and “emotive” annotations while capturing expressions in a range of languages and cultures.<\/p>\n "embed-youtube embed--youtube embed embed-jetpack breakout embed--video\" style=\"text-align:center; display: block;\"> "youtube-player embed-iframe embed-iframe--youtube\" width=\"640\" height=\"360\" src=\"https:\/\/www.youtube.com\/embed\/GZqYr8_Q7DE?version=3&rel=1&showsearch=0&showinfo=1&iv_load_policy=1&fs=1&hl=en-US&autohide=2&wmode=transparent\" allowfullscreen=\"true\" style=\"border:0;\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts allow-same-origin allow-popups allow-presentation\"><\/iframe><\/span><\/p>\n “We’re setting our sights on training AI models that can grasp a wide variety of languages and truly understand different cultural settings,” Noriy said. “We’re working on creating models that ‘get’ languages and cultures, using videos that show real emotions and expressions.”<\/p>\n Once volunteers submit a clip to LAION’s database, they can repeat the process anew — there’s no limit to the number of clips a single volunteer can annotate. LAION hopes to gather roughly 10,000 samples over the next few months, and — optimistically — between 100,000 to 1 million by next year.<\/p>\n “We have passionate community members who, driven by the vision of democratizing AI models and data sets, willingly contribute annotations in their free time,” Noriy said. “Their motivation is the shared dream of creating an empathic and emotionally intelligent open source AI that’s accessible to all.”<\/p>\n The pitfalls of emotion detection<\/h2>\n Aside from Amazon’s attempts with Alexa, startups and tech giants alike have explored developing AI that can detect emotions — for purposes ranging from sales training to preventing drowsiness-induced accidents.<\/p>\n In 2016, Apple "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2016\/01\/07\/apple-dives-deeper-into-artificial-intelligence-by-acquiring-emotient\/\">acquired<\/a> Emotient, a San Diego firm working on AI algorithms that analyze facial expressions. Snatched up by Sweden-based Smart Eye last May, "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/affectiva\/\">Affectiva<\/a> — an MIT spin-out — once claimed its technology could detect anger or frustration in speech in 1.2 seconds. And speech recognition platform Nuance, which Microsoft "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/03\/04\/after-clearing-all-regulatory-hurdles-microsoft-closes-20b-nuance-deal\/\">purchased<\/a> in April 2021, has demoed a product for cars that analyzes driver emotions from their facial cues.<\/p>\n Other players in the budding emotion detection and recognition space include Hume, HireVue and "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2018\/05\/22\/realeyes-which-uses-ai-and-a-front-facing-camera-to-read-viewers-emotions-raises-16-2m\/\">Realeyes<\/a>, whose technology is being applied to gauge how certain segments of viewers respond to certain ads. Some employers are using emotion-detecting tech to "ea kj\" href=\"https:\/\/www.wsj.com\/articles\/artificial-intelligence-the-robots-are-now-hiring-moving-upstream-1537435820\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener ugc nofollow\">evaluate potential employees<\/a>\u00a0by scoring them on\u00a0 "ea kj\" href=\"https:\/\/edition.cnn.com\/2020\/01\/15\/tech\/ai-job-interview\/index.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener ugc nofollow\">empathy<\/a> and "ea kj\" href=\"https:\/\/www.wired.com\/story\/job-screening-service-halts-facial-analysis-applicants\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener ugc nofollow\">emotional intelligence<\/a>. Schools have deployed it to monitor students\u2019 engagement\u00a0 "ea kj\" href=\"https:\/\/www.tandfonline.com\/doi\/full\/10.1080\/17439884.2020.1686014\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener ugc nofollow\">in the classroom<\/a> — and remotely "ea kj\" href=\"https:\/\/edition.cnn.com\/2021\/02\/16\/tech\/emotion-recognition-ai-education-spc-intl-hnk\/index.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener ugc nofollow\">at home<\/a>. And emotion-detecting AI has been used by governments to identify “ "ea kj\" href=\"https:\/\/www.article19.org\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/01\/ER-Tech-China-Report.pdf\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener ugc nofollow\">dangerous people<\/a>” and tested at border control stops in the "https:\/\/theconversation.com\/ai-facial-analysis-is-scientifically-questionable-should-we-be-using-it-for-border-control-155474\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">U.S., Hungary, Latvia and Greece<\/a>.<\/p>\n The LAION team envisions, for their part, helpful, unproblematic applications of the tech across robotics, psychology, professional training, education and even gaming. Schuhmann paints a picture of robots that offer support and companionship, virtual assistants that sense when someone feels lonely or anxious and tools that aid in diagnosing psychological disorders.<\/p>\n It’s a techno utopia. The problem is, most emotion detection is on shaky scientific ground.<\/p>\n Few, if any, universal markers of emotion exist — putting the accuracy of emotion-detecting AI into question. The majority of emotion-detecting systems were built on the work of psychologist Paul Ekman, published in the ’70s. But subsequent research — including Ekman’s own — supports the common-sense notion that there’s major differences in the way people from different backgrounds express how they\u2019re feeling.<\/p>\n For example, the expression "https:\/\/www.theguardian.com\/technology\/2020\/feb\/16\/ai-systems-claiming-to-read-emotions-pose-discrimination-risks\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">supposedly<\/a> universal for fear is a stereotype for a threat or anger in Malaysia. In one of his later works, Ekman suggested that American and Japanese students tend to react to violent films very differently, with Japanese students adopting “a completely different set of expressions” if someone else is in the room — particularly an authority figure.<\/p>\n Voices, too, cover a broad range of characteristics, including those of people with disabilities, conditions like autism and who speak in other languages and dialects such as African-American Vernacular English (AAVE). A native French speaker taking a survey in English might pause or pronounce a word with some uncertainty — which could be misconstrued by someone unfamiliar as an emotion marker.<\/p>\n Indeed, a big part of the problem with emotion-detecting AI is bias — implicit and explicit bias brought by the annotators whose contributions are used to train emotion-detecting models.<\/p>\n In a 2019 "https:\/\/homes.cs.washington.edu\/~msap\/pdfs\/sap2019risk.pdf\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">study<\/a>, for instance, scientists found that labelers are more likely to annotate phrases in AAVE more toxic than their general American English equivalents. Sexual orientation and gender identity can heavily "https:\/\/dl.acm.org\/doi\/pdf\/10.1145\/3555088\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">influence<\/a> which words and phrases an annotator perceives as toxic as well — as can outright prejudice. Several commonly used open source image data sets have been found to contain racist, sexist and otherwise "https:\/\/venturebeat.com\/2020\/07\/01\/mit-takes-down-80-million-tiny-images-data-set-due-to-racist-and-offensive-content\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">offensive<\/a> labels from annotators.<\/p>\n The downstream effects can be quite dramatic.<\/p>\n Retorio, an AI hiring platform, was found to react differently to the same candidate in different outfits, such as glasses and headscarves. In a 2020 MIT "https:\/\/venturebeat.com\/2020\/11\/23\/training-ai-algorithms-on-mostly-smiling-faces-reduces-accuracy-and-introduces-bias-according-to-research\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">study<\/a>, researchers showed that face-analyzing algorithms could become biased toward certain facial expressions, like smiling — reducing their accuracy. More recent "https:\/\/singularityhub.com\/2019\/01\/11\/understanding-the-hidden-bias-in-emotion-reading-ais\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">work<\/a> implies that popular emotional analysis tools tend to assign more negative emotions to Black men\u2019s faces than white faces.<\/p>\n Respecting the process<\/h2>\n So how will the LAION team combat these biases — making certain, for instance, that white people don’t outnumber Black people in the data set; that nonbinary people aren’t assigned the wrong gender; and that those with mood disorders aren’t mislabeled with emotions they didn’t intend to express?<\/p>\n It’s not totally clear.<\/p>\n Schuhmann claims the training data submission process for Open Empathic isn’t an “open door” and that LAION has systems in place to “ensure the integrity of contributions.”<\/p>\n “We can validate a user’s intention and consistently check for the quality of annotations,” he added.<\/p>\n But LAION’s previous data sets haven’t exactly been pristine.<\/p>\n "https:\/\/www.insider.com\/chatgpt-is-like-many-other-ai-models-rife-with-bias-2023-1\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Some analyses<\/a> "https:\/\/www.bloomberg.com\/graphics\/2023-generative-ai-bias\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">of<\/a> LAION ~400M — a LAION image training set, which the group attempted to curate with automated tools — turned up photos depicting sexual assault, rape, hate symbols and graphic violence. LAION ~400M is also "https:\/\/www.deeplearning.ai\/the-batch\/crawl-the-web-absorb-the-bias\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">rife<\/a> with bias, for example returning images of men but not women for words like “CEO” and pictures of Middle Eastern Men for “terrorist.”<\/p>\n Schuhmann’s placing trust in the community to serve as a check this go-around.<\/p>\n “We believe in the power of hobby scientists and enthusiasts from all over the world coming together and contributing to our data sets,” he said. “While we’re open and collaborative, we prioritize quality and authenticity in our data.”<\/p>\n As far as how any emotion-detecting AI trained on the Open Empathic data set — biased or no — is used, LAION is intent on upholding its open source philosophy — even if that means the AI might be abused.<\/p>\n “Using AI to understand emotions is a powerful venture, but it’s not without its challenges,” Robert Kaczmarczyk, a LAION co-founder and physician at the Technical University of Munich, said via email. “Like any tool out there, it can be used for both good and bad. Imagine if just a small group had access to advanced technology, while most of the public was in the dark. This imbalance could lead to misuse or even manipulation by the few who have control over this technology.”<\/p>\n Where it concerns AI, laissez faire approaches sometimes come back to bite model’s creators — as evidenced by how Stable Diffusion is now being used to create "https:\/\/apnews.com\/article\/ai-artificial-intelligence-child-sexual-abuse-c8f17de56d41f05f55286eb6177138d2\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">child sexual abuse material<\/a> and "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/08\/24\/deepfakes-for-all-uncensored-ai-art-model-prompts-ethics-questions\/\">nonconsensual deepfakes<\/a>.<\/p>\n Certain privacy and human rights advocates, including European Digital Rights and Access Now, have "https:\/\/edri.org\/our-work\/emotion-misrecognition\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">called<\/a> "https:\/\/www.accessnow.org\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/05\/Prohibit-emotion-recognition-in-the-Artificial-Intelligence-Act.pdf\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">for<\/a> a blanket ban on emotion recognition. The "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/eu-ai-act\/\">EU AI Act<\/a>, the recently enacted European Union law that establishes a governance framework for AI, bars the use of emotion recognition in policing, border management, workplaces and schools. And some companies have voluntarily "https:\/\/www.independent.co.uk\/tech\/microsoft-ai-facial-recognition-artificial-intelligence-b2106615.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">pulled<\/a> their emotion-detecting AI, like Microsoft, in the face of public blowback.<\/p>\n LAION seems comfortable with the level of risk involved, though — and has faith in the open development process.<\/p>\n “We welcome researchers to poke around, suggest changes, and spot issues,” Kaczmarczyk said. “And just like how Wikipedia thrives on its community contributions, Open Empathic is fueled by community involvement, making sure it’s transparent and safe.”<\/p>\n Transparent? Sure. Safe? Time will tell.<\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":" In 2019, Amazon upgraded its Alexa assistant with a feature that enabled it to detect when a customer was likely frustrated — and respond with proportionately more sympathy. It's an ethical minefield.\" \/>\n "canonical\" href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/27\/a-group-behind-stable-diffusion-wants-to-open-source-emotion-detecting-ai\/\" \/>\n "og:locale\" content=\"en_US\" \/>\n "og:type\" content=\"article\" \/>\n "og:title\" content=\"A group behind Stable Diffusion wants to open source emotion-detecting AI | TechCrunch\" \/>\n "og:description\" content=\"LAION, one of the groups behind Stable Diffusion, is trying to create emotion-detecting AI. s-team-to-study-catastrophic-risks-including-nuclear-threats\/","title":{"rendered":"OpenAI forms team to study ‘catastrophic’ AI risks, including nuclear threats"},"content":{"rendered":" "speakable-summary\">OpenAI today "https:\/\/openai.com\/blog\/frontier-risk-and-preparedness\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">announced<\/a> that it’s created a new team to assess, evaluate and probe AI models to protect against what it describes as “catastrophic risks.”<\/p>\n The team, called Preparedness, will be led by Aleksander Madry, the director of MIT’s Center for Deployable Machine Learning. (Madry joined OpenAI in May as “head of Preparedness,” "https:\/\/www.linkedin.com\/in\/aleksander-madry-61115b233\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">according<\/a> to LinkedIn.) Preparedness’ chief responsibilities will be tracking, forecasting and protecting against the dangers of future AI systems, ranging from their ability to persuade and fool humans (like in phishing attacks) to their malicious code-generating capabilities.<\/p>\n Some of the risk categories Preparedness is charged with studying seem more\u00a0.\u00a0.\u00a0.\u00a0 far-fetched<\/em> than others. For example, in a blog post, OpenAI lists “chemical, biological, radiological and nuclear” threats as areas of top concern where it pertains to AI models.<\/p>\n OpenAI CEO Sam Altman is a "https:\/\/www.cnbc.com\/2023\/05\/31\/ai-poses-human-extinction-risk-sam-altman-and-other-tech-leaders-warn.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">noted<\/a> AI doomsayer, often airing fears — whether for optics or out of personal conviction — that AI “may lead to human extinction.” But telegraphing that OpenAI might\u00a0 actually<\/em> devote resources to studying scenarios straight out of sci-fi dystopian novels is a step further than this writer expected, frankly.<\/p>\n The company’s open to studying “less obvious” — and more grounded — areas of AI risk, too, it says. To coincide with the launch of the Preparedness team, OpenAI is soliciting ideas for risk studies from the community, with a $25,000 prize and a job at Preparedness on the line for the top ten submissions.<\/p>\n “Imagine we gave you unrestricted access to OpenAI\u2019s Whisper (transcription), Voice (text-to-speech), GPT-4V, and DALLE\u00b73 models, and you were a malicious actor,” one of the questions in the "https:\/\/openai.com\/form\/preparedness-challenge\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">contest entry<\/a> reads. “Consider the most unique, while still being probable, potentially catastrophic misuse of the model.”<\/p>\n OpenAI says that the Preparedness team will also be charged with formulating a “risk-informed development policy,” which will detail OpenAI’s approach to building AI model evaluations and monitoring tooling, the company’s risk-mitigating actions and its governance structure for oversight across the model development process. It’s meant to complement OpenAI’s other work in the discipline of AI safety, the company says, with focus on both the pre- and post-model deployment phases.<\/p> "piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n “We believe that . . . AI models, which will exceed the capabilities currently present in the most advanced existing models, have the potential to benefit all of humanity,” OpenAI writes in the aforementioned blog post. “But they also pose increasingly severe risks\u00a0.\u00a0.\u00a0.\u00a0We need to ensure we have the understanding and infrastructure needed for the safety of highly capable AI systems.”<\/p>\n The unveiling of Preparedness — during a major "https:\/\/www.gov.uk\/government\/topical-events\/ai-safety-summit-2023\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">U.K. government summit on AI safety<\/a>, not so coincidentally — comes after OpenAI announced that it would form a team to study, steer and control emergent forms of “ "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/07\/05\/openai-is-forming-a-new-team-to-bring-superintelligent-ai-under-control\/\">superintelligent<\/a>” AI. It’s Altman’s belief — along with the belief of Ilya Sutskever, OpenAI’s chief scientist and a co-founder — that AI with intelligence exceeding that of humans could arrive within the decade, and that this AI won\u2019t necessarily be benevolent — necessitating research into ways to limit and restrict it.<\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":" OpenAI today announced that it’s created a new team to assess, evaluate and probe AI models to protect against what it describes as “catastrophic risks.” The team, called Preparedness, will be led by Aleksander Madry, the director of MIT’s Center for Deployable Machine Learning. (Madry joined OpenAI in May as “head of Preparedness,” according to […]<\/p>\n","protected":false},"author":133574536,"featured_media":2555746,"comment_status":"open","ping_status":"closed","sticky":false,"template":"","format":"standard","meta":{"amp_status":"","relegenceEntities":[],"relegenceSubjects":[],"carmot_uuid":"92949642-de5c-35d0-9762-d7dbf1019bc4","footnotes":"","apple_news_api_created_at":"2023-10-26T17:57:29Z","apple_news_api_id":"d7dbc141-7d2a-4259-a884-017a0dc57b69","apple_news_api_modified_at":"2023-10-26T21:30:26Z","apple_news_api_revision":"AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAQ==","apple_news_api_share_url":"https:\/\/apple.news\/A19vBQX0qQlmohAF6DcV7aQ","apple_news_coverimage":0,"apple_news_coverimage_caption":"","apple_news_is_hidden":false,"apple_news_is_paid":false,"apple_news_is_preview":false,"apple_news_is_sponsored":false,"apple_news_maturity_rating":"","apple_news_metadata":"\"\"","apple_news_pullquote":"","apple_news_pullquote_position":"","apple_news_slug":"","apple_news_sections":"\"\"","apple_news_suppress_video_url":false,"apple_news_use_image_component":false},"categories":[577047203,577065682],"tags":[14067,576717904,421223872,34932559,668],"crunchbase_tag":[],"tc_stories_tax":[],"tc_ec_category":[],"tc_event":[],"tc_regions_tax":[],"yoast_head":"\n OpenAI forms team to study 'catastrophic' AI risks, including nuclear threats | TechCrunch<\/title>\n "description\" content=\"AI has formed a new team, Preparedness, to study the 'catastrophic risks' that might be associated with future AI systems -- including nuclear risks.\" \/>\n "canonical\" ndered":"SaaS follow-on rounds see a slowdown, but it won’t last forever"},"content":{"rendered":" "speakable-summary\"> "featured__span-first-words\">Global venture funding<\/span> has been rather gloomy as of late, with "https:\/\/news.crunchbase.com\/venture\/global-venture-funding-instacart-klaviyo-q3-2023\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">data<\/a> from Crunchbase showing that investments fell in Q3 despite a late-stage rebound led by large AI deals.<\/p>\n And the story’s no different for SaaS startups.<\/p>\n In May, net new SaaS sales came down from a spike in Q1 while churn "https:\/\/www.paddle.com\/blog\/b2b-saas-index-market-update-june-2023\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">worsened<\/a>, spurred by reduced business-to-business budgets and higher borrowing costs. At the same time, extension rounds \u2014 an important indicator of a sector’s overall health \u2014 declined.<\/p>\n PitchBook data compiled for TechCrunch shows that U.S. VC follow-on activity in SaaS dropped from a high of $9.7 billion across 270 deals in March to a low of $1.5 billion across 131 deals in October. The decrease in deal count has been consistent: Each month since June, the total number of SaaS follow-on deals has dipped by around 10 to 40 deals month-to-month.<\/p>\n The caveat is that total SaaS extension deal value has been holding steady at between $1.5 billion and $2.9 billion from April to October. But that simply indicates that a smaller cohort of startups has been securing disproportionately larger extension rounds.
"extra-crunch-offer-container\"><\/div>","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":" The exit market for SaaS dried up in the second half of 2022, which saw the lowest exit activity since aims to connect company data to LLMs ‘securely’"},"content":{"rendered":" "speakable-summary\"> "http:\/\/credal.ai\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Credal.ai<\/a>, a Y Combinator-backed startup that gives enterprises a way to connect their internal data to text-generating, cloud-hosted AI models, has raised $4.8 million in a seed round led by Spark Capital.<\/p>\n Credal was founded by Jack Fischer and Ravin Thambapillai, who previously worked at Palantir and bonded over a mutual interest in security and compliance. Ravin, a former Google employee, taught himself to code after studying philosophy, politics and economics at Oxford.<\/p>\n “We realized that, with our backgrounds in enterprise data security and AI from Palantir, we were in a unique position from which to build an AI data platform that enterprises could actually trust,” Fischer told TechCrunch in an email interview.<\/p>\n Fischer and Thambapillai initially set out to build what they describe as a “decision-making assistant” for enterprises that’d use large language models (LLMs) — models along the lines of "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/chatgpt\/\">ChatGPT<\/a> — to read documents and give advice on strategic, C Suite-level decisions. But the project eventually morphed into something broader: a tool to connect data from internal data sources to outside LLMs.<\/p>\n As the platform exists today, Credal can be used to build general knowledge or domain-specific, AI-powered chatbots for a range of use cases. For example, a company could tap Credal to create a bot that answers security questions about software that the company licenses, drawing on the latest documentation.<\/p>\n Credal doesn’t serve LLMs itself. Rather, it sits between users submitting prompts (e.g. “What’s the latest version of this software?”) and an API from a third-party LLM provider like OpenAI or Anthropic, acting as a “co-pilot” that can be deployed in existing apps like Slack.<\/p>\n Credal attempts to automatically direct prompts to the “most appropriate” LLM if a company’s using more than one, based on factors like the sensitivity of the data being submitted, cost, company policy and a model’s technical capabilities. In some cases, it employs more than one LLM to accomplish a task — for instance, using Anthropic’s Claude and GPT-4 to structure company documents.<\/p> "piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n Plenty of platforms offer ways to connect company data to LLMs — see "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/07\/19\/unstructured-which-offers-tools-to-prep-enterprise-data-for-llms-raises-25m\/\">Unstructured<\/a>, "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/12\/deasie-wants-to-rank-and-filter-data-to-make-generative-ai-more-reliable\/\">Deasie<\/a> and "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/06\/06\/llamaindex-adds-private-data-to-large-language-models\/\">LlamaIndex<\/a>. And OpenAI’s "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/03\/23\/openai-connects-chatgpt-to-the-internet\/\">expanding<\/a> its built-in plug-in framework. But Credal’s unique spin on this is a strong emphasis on compliance and security — at least the way Fischer tells it.<\/p>\n Credal attempts to automatically redact, anonymize and otherwise warn when sensitive data is about to be sent off-network, say to an LLM hosted on a public cloud. And it provides logs that show what data’s been shared with which LLMs.<\/p>\n Data sent to Credal\u00a0 is<\/em> retained by default and kept for 30 days after accounts expire — which might give some companies pause. But admins can<\/em> change this and choose to wipe data at any time, Fischer emphasizes.<\/p>\n Fischer also claims that Credal is one of the few vendors of its kind to be registered under the Data Privacy Framework, the recent U.S.-EU agreement that governs the transfer of personal data between the two countries. That’s enabled it to win contracts with publicly traded, regulated European enterprises like Wise, Fischer says.<\/p>\n “IT departments at enterprises want visibility, and control, over how AI is being used within their organization,” he added. “Credal gives them [this transparency] in a standard format across multiple LLM providers, providing fine-grained data controls over who can access which models, what data can be used by each user and for what purposes … Unlike other ‘AI on your data’ systems, Credal automatically mirrors the permissions of the source systems it connects to, so when a user asks a question, the AI responds from only company documents that are both relevant and<\/i> accessible to that user.”<\/p>\n Since launching in April, Fischer claims that Credal has handled over a quarter of a million LLM calls and ingested around 100,000 corporate documents. The company has 11 customers currently, several of which have signed “six-figure” contracts, according to Fischer.<\/p>\n With the capital from the seed round, Credal plans to expand its headcount (which stands at five employees at present) and “expand the product to cover more data sources and perform more sophisticated data retrieval,” Fischer says.<\/p>\n “The AI industry at the moment is suffering a relative imbalance between the huge enthusiasm and the as-yet still relatively small number of companies using LLMs to create real-world value,” Fischer said. “Credal is solving that by embedding deeply with a small number of amazing enterprises and actually solving their problems end-to-end.”<\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":" Credal.ai, a Y Combinator-backed startup that gives enterprises a way to connect their internal data to text-generating, cloud-hosted AI models, has raised $4.8 million in a seed round led by Spark Capital. Credal was founded by Jack Fischer and Ravin Thambapillai, who previously worked at Palantir and bonded over a mutual interest in security and […]<\/p>\n","protected":false},"author":133574536,"featured_media":2573656,"comment_status":"open","ping_status":"closed","sticky":false,"template":"","format":"standard","meta":{"amp_status":"","relegenceEntities":[],"relegenceSubjects":[],"carmot_uuid":"7333ba22-766d-395c-b8b1-d1d60513cee7","footnotes":"","apple_news_api_created_at":"2023-10-26T13:00:56Z","apple_news_api_id":"51affdff-bcf1-459a-bbea-5b864772300b","apple_news_api_modified_at":"2023-10-26T17:05:57Z","apple_news_api_revision":"AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAg==","apple_news_api_share_url":"https:\/\/apple.news\/AUa_9_7zxRZq76luGR3IwCw","apple_news_coverimage":0,"apple_news_coverimage_caption":"","apple_news_is_hidden":false,"apple_news_is_paid":false,"apple_news_is_preview":false,"apple_news_is_sponsored":false,"apple_news_maturity_rating":"","apple_news_metadata":"\"\"","apple_news_pullquote":"","apple_news_pullquote_position":"","apple_news_slug":"","apple_news_sections":"\"\"","apple_news_suppress_video_url":false,"apple_news_use_image_component":false},"categories":[577047203,449557044,20429],"tags":[14067,577201974,15328,20250,576717904,577006963,577018669,443087,4621],"crunchbase_tag":[213674513],"tc_stories_tax":[],"tc_ec_category":[],"tc_event":[],"tc_regions_tax":[],"yoast_head":"\n name=search_term_string"}],"inLanguage":"en-US"},{"@type":"Organization","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#organization","name":"TechCrunch","alternateName":"TC","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/","logo":{"@type":"ImageObject","inLanguage":"en-US","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","contentUrl":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","width":1200,"height":1200,"caption":"TechCrunch"},"image":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/"},"sameAs":["https:\/\/www.facebook.com\/techcrunch","https:\/\/twitter.com\/TechCrunch","https:\/\/mstdn.social\/@TechCrunch","https:\/\/bsky.app\/profile\/techcrunch.bsky.social","https:\/\/www.threads.net\/@techcrunch"]}]}},"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/4621"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=4621"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_battlefield?tags=4621"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=4621"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_unified_video?tags=4621"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=4621"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[{"id":213674513,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?taxonomy=_tc_cb_tag_taxonomy&term=spark-capital-organization","name":"spark-capital-organization","slug":"spark-capital-organization","taxonomy":"_tc_cb_tag_taxonomy","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/crunchbase_tag\/213674513"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/crunchbase_tag"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/_tc_cb_tag_taxonomy"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?crunchbase_tag=213674513"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2618806,"date":"2023-10-26T06:00:05","date_gmt":"2023-10-26T13:00:05","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2618806"},"modified":"2023-10-26T08:25:23","modified_gmt":"2023-10-26T15:25:23","slug":"outset-is-using-gpt-4-to-make-user-surveys-better","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/26\/outset-is-using-gpt-4-to-make-user-surveys-better\/","title":{"rendered":"Outset is using GPT-4 to make user surveys better"},"content":{"rendered":" "speakable-summary\">Getting answers to tough, qualitative questions about products from users can be costly, both in terms of time and money.<\/p>\n At least, that was the experience of Aaron Cannon, a former strategist at Deloitte, where he was responsible for facilitating research projects for Deloitte clients. Cannon and his team would spend hundreds of hours on a client project, only to have to devote additional time — and resources — to scheduling and moderating interviews with the said client’s customers.<\/p>\n "ltr\">“Enterprise decision makers expect faster and faster results from insights teams,” Cannon told TechCrunch in an email interview. “Researchers are feeling that pressure every day, particularly after being hit hard by 2022 layoffs. The biggest risk to the industry today is that the increasing speed of decision making leads to a decreasing ability for insights functions to keep up. That\u2019s why researchers need the tools to accelerate and amplify their work.”<\/p>\n So Cannon teamed up with Michael Hess, who he met while working at Untapped, a talent recruiting startup, to found "https:\/\/outset.ai\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Outset<\/a>. A Y Combinator-backed company, Outset autonomously conducts — and synthesizes — interviews.<\/p>\n "ltr\">“The broader slowdown and associated layoffs have hit research and insights teams disproportionately hard. But the demands from business leaders to make more informed and strategic decisions has not slowed down, leading to expectations of doing more with less,” Cannon said. “This is a tailwind for "il\">Outset<\/span> as people look to technology to amplify their work.”<\/p>\n "attachment_2618906\" style=\"width: 1034px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"> "caption-attachment-2618906\" decoding=\"async\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"size-full wp-image-2618906\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/52d11205-52b7-48e9-9c32-a91f35695242.gif\" alt=\"Outset\" width=\"1024\" height=\"1036\" \/> "caption-attachment-2618906\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"> Image Credits:<\/strong> Outset<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n "ltr\">Outset taps "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/gpt-4\/\">GPT-4<\/a>, OpenAI’s flagship text-generating AI model, to lead interviews with participants in research studies. How, exactly? Outset users create a survey and share the link with prospective survey takers. Then, Outset — powered by GPT-4 — follows up with respondents to clarify, probe on answers and create a “conversational rapport” for deeper responses.<\/p> "piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n For every question, GPT-4 generates themes, tallies up counts and highlights quotes to “uncover the story,” as Cannon puts it.<\/p>\n "ltr\">“Today, much of the work to collect and analyze qualitative data is done manually. In that way, we\u2019re competing with the late nights I used to spend reading transcripts and scheduling interviews as a consultant,” Cannon said. “We believe that "il\">Outset<\/span> will grow the market for research, making user insights faster and more accessible to more teams across the business.”<\/p>\n "ltr\">It’s early days for Outset. But, despite GPT-4’s "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/17\/microsoft-affiliated-research-finds-flaws-in-gtp-4\/\">imperfections<\/a> and "https:\/\/www.fastcompany.com\/90851964\/chatgpt-summarization\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">limitations<\/a>, Outset’s already seen some success with a household brand: WeightWatchers. WeightWatchers was able to conduct and synthesize over 100 interviews in 24 hours, according to Cannon, the results of which are now being used to propose a new framework at WeightWatchers for user segmentation.<\/p>\n "ltr\">“We\u2019re currently working with 15 enterprise insights teams at companies like Opendoor and other large consumer-oriented companies to help them make smarter, faster user-centered decisions than ever before,” Cannon said.<\/p>\n "attachment_2618907\" style=\"width: 1034px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"> "caption-attachment-2618907\" decoding=\"async\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"size-full wp-image-2618907\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/bab1ab87-3b42-462f-a046-8fbead045dff.gif\" alt=\"Outset\" width=\"1024\" height=\"848\" \/> "caption-attachment-2618907\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"> Image Credits:<\/strong> Outset<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n "ltr\">Outset, which recently raised $3.8 million in a funding round led by Adverb Ventures with participation from Weekend Fund and Jack Altman, Sam Altman’s brother, plans to expand the size of its team from four full-time employees to six by the end of the year.<\/p>\n “We just raised our seed and our team is small, so we\u2019re keeping our burn rate low,” Cannon said. “Despite the broader economic slowdown, there’s increasing demand for AI-powered tools in everyday knowledge work, giving us another tailwind. Between our seed round of funding, low burn and accelerating tailwinds, we’re well-positioned to weather any storm.”<\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":" Getting answers to tough, qualitative questions about products from users can be costly, both in terms of time and money. At least, that was the experience of Aaron Cannon, a former strategist at Deloitte, where he was responsible for facilitating research projects for Deloitte clients. Cannon and his team would spend hundreds of hours on name=search_term_string"}],"inLanguage":"en-US"},{"@type":"Organization","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#organization","name":"TechCrunch","alternateName":"TC","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/","logo":{"@type":"ImageObject","inLanguage":"en-US","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","contentUrl":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","width":1200,"height":1200,"caption":"TechCrunch"},"image":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/"},"sameAs":["https:\/\/www.facebook.com\/techcrunch","https:\/\/twitter.com\/TechCrunch","https:\/\/mstdn.social\/@TechCrunch","https:\/\/bsky.app\/profile\/techcrunch.bsky.social","https:\/\/www.threads.net\/@techcrunch"]}]}},"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/66455"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=66455"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_battlefield?tags=66455"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=66455"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_unified_video?tags=66455"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=66455"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2619765,"date":"2023-10-25T09:11:46","date_gmt":"2023-10-25T16:11:46","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2619765"},"modified":"2023-10-25T16:44:03","modified_gmt":"2023-10-25T23:44:03","slug":"ai-titans-throw-a-tiny-bone-to-ai-safety-researchers","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/25\/ai-titans-throw-a-tiny-bone-to-ai-safety-researchers\/","title":{"rendered":"AI titans throw a (tiny) bone to AI safety researchers"},"content":{"rendered":" "speakable-summary\">The "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/07\/26\/openai-google-microsoft-and-anthropic-form-body-to-oversee-safe-frontier-ai-development\/\">Frontier Model Forum<\/a>, an industry body focused on studying “frontier” AI models along the lines of "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/gpt-4\/\">GPT-4<\/a> and "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/chatgpt\/\">ChatGPT<\/a>, today announced that it’ll pledge $10 million toward a new fund to advance research on tools for “testing and evaluating the most capable AI models.”<\/p>\n The fund, says the Frontier Model Forum — whose members include Anthropic, Google, Microsoft and OpenAI — will support researchers affiliated with academic institutions, research institutions and startups, with initial funding to come from both the Frontier Model Forum and its philanthropic partners, the Patrick J. McGovern Foundation, the David and Lucile Packard Foundation, former Google CEO Eric Schmidt and Estonian billionaire Jaan Tallinn.<\/p>\n The fund will be administered by the Meridian Institute, a nonprofit based in Washington, D.C., which will put out a call for an unspecified number of proposals “within the next few months,” the Frontier Model Forum says. The Institute’s work will be supported by an advisory committee of external experts, experts from AI companies and “individuals with experience in grantmaking,” added the Frontier Model Forum — without specifying who exactly those experts and individuals are or the size of the advisory committee in question.<\/p>\n “We’re expecting additional contributions from other partners,” reads a press release put out by the Frontier Model Forum on a "http:\/\/freehandhotels.com\/new-york\/broken-shaker\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">number<\/a> of "https:\/\/openai.com\/blog\/frontier-model-forum-updates\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">official blogs<\/a>. “The primary focus of the fund will be supporting the development of new model evaluations and techniques … to help develop and test evaluation techniques for potentially dangerous capabilities of frontier systems.”<\/p>\n Indeed, $10 million isn’t chump change. (More accurately, it’s $10 million in pledges<\/em> — The David and Lucile Packard Foundation hasn’t formally committed funding yet.) But in the context of AI safety research, it seems rather, well, conservative — <\/em>at least compared to what members of The Frontier Model Forum have spent on their commercial endeavors.<\/p>\n This year alone, Anthropic\u00a0 "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/09\/25\/amazon-to-invest-up-to-4-billion-in-ai-startup-anthropic\/\">raised<\/a> billions of dollars from Amazon to develop a next-gen AI assistant, "https:\/\/www.theverge.com\/2023\/2\/3\/23584540\/google-anthropic-investment-300-million-openai-chatgpt-rival-claude\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">following<\/a> a $300 investment from Google. Microsoft "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/01\/23\/microsoft-invests-billions-more-dollars-in-openai-extends-partnership\/\">pledged<\/a> $10 billion toward OpenAI, and OpenAI — whose annual "https:\/\/www.theinformation.com\/articles\/openais-revenue-crossed-1-3-billion-annualized-rate-ceo-tells-staff#:~:text=OpenAI's%20Revenue%20Crossed%20%241.3%20Billion%20Annualized%20Rate%2C%20CEO%20Tells%20Staff,-By&text=Photo%3A%20Sam%20Altman%2C%20CEO%20of,with%20knowledge%20of%20the%20matter.\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">revenue<\/a> is well over $1 billion — is "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/09\/26\/openai-is-reportedly-raising-funds-at-a-valuation-of-80-billion-to-90-billion\/\">reportedly<\/a> in talks to sell shares in a move that would boost its valuation to as high as $90 billion.<\/p>\n The fund’s also small in comparison to other AI safety grants.<\/p> "piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n Open Philanthropy, the grant-making and research foundation co-founded by Facebook founder Dustin Moskovitz, has donated about $307 million on AI safety, according to an "https:\/\/www.lesswrong.com\/posts\/WGpFFJo2uFe5ssgEb\/an-overview-of-the-ai-safety-funding-situation\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">analysis<\/a> on the blog Less Wrong. The public benefit corporation The Survival and Flourishing Fund — furnished primarily by Tallinn — has given around $30 million to AI safety projects. And the U.S. National Science Foundation has said that it’ll spend $20 million on AI safety research over the next two years, supported in part by Open Philanthropy grants.<\/p>\n AI safety researchers won’t necessarily be training GPT-4-level models from scratch. But even smaller, less capable models that they might wish to test would be expensive to develop with today’s hardware, ranging in cost from "https:\/\/www.techtimes.com\/articles\/292051\/20230529\/nvidia-announces-9-6m-drop-in-cost-when-using-its-gpus-for-ai-llm-training.htm\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">hundreds of thousands of dollars to millions<\/a>. That’s not factoring in other overhead, like the salaries to pay the researchers. (Data scientists "https:\/\/www.forbes.com\/sites\/gilpress\/2022\/06\/14\/a-booming-market-for-ai-skills-with-salaries-topping-300000\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">don’t come cheap<\/a>.)<\/p>\n The Frontier Model Forum alludes to a larger fund down the line. If that comes to fruition, it might just<\/em> have a chance at moving the needle on AI safety research — if we’re to trust the fund’s decidedly for-profit backers to refrain from exercising undue influence over the research. But no matter how you slice it, the initial tranche seems far too limited to accomplish much.<\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":" The Frontier Model Forum, an industry body focused on studying “frontier” AI models along the lines of GPT-4 and ChatGPT, today announced that it’ll pledge $10 million toward a new fund to advance research on tools for “testing and evaluating the most capable AI models.” The fund, says the Frontier Model Forum — whose members […]<\/p>\n","protected":false},"author":133574536,"featured_media":2483870,"comment_status":"open","ping_status":"closed","sticky":false,"template":"","format":"standard","meta":{"amp_status":"","relegenceEntities":[],"relegenceSubjects":[],"carmot_uuid":"b434de14-cedd-34fb-8d39-2b7ecea6f9d5","footnotes":"","apple_news_api_created_at":"2023-10-25T16:11:51Z","apple_news_api_id":"c714b3c1-5102-4c9b-970c-ee6656540845","apple_news_api_modified_at":"2023-10-25T23:43:57Z","apple_news_api_revision":"AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAA==","apple_news_api_share_url":"https:\/\/apple.news\/AxxSzwVECTJuXDO5mVlQIRQ","apple_news_coverimage":0,"apple_news_coverimage_caption":"","apple_news_is_hidden":false,"apple_news_is_paid":false,"apple_news_is_preview":false,"apple_news_is_sponsored":false,"apple_news_maturity_rating":"","apple_news_metadata":"\"\"","apple_news_pullquote":"","apple_news_pullquote_position":"","apple_news_slug":"","apple_news_sections":"\"\"","apple_news_suppress_video_url":false,"apple_news_use_image_component":false},"categories":[577047203],"tags":[14067,577169118,175823,668,2136],"crunchbase_tag":[],"tc_stories_tax":[],"tc_ec_category":[],"tc_event":[],"tc_regions_tax":[],"yoast_head":"\n
