25\/the-house-fund-aims-to-invest-a-fresh-115m-in-berkeley-affiliated-startups\/","title":{"rendered":"The House Fund aims to invest a fresh $115M in Berkeley-affiliated startups"},"content":{"rendered":" "speakable-summary\">The House Fund, the pre-seed and early-stage venture capital fund focused on UC Berkeley startups, specifically AI startups, today announced that it has closed its third tranche — Fund III — at $115 million.<\/p>\n With the close of Fund III, "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/06\/15\/pieter-abbeel-and-ken-goldberg-on-generative-ai-applications\/\">Ken Goldberg<\/a>, the UC Berkeley professor and prolific roboticist, will join The House Fund as a part-time partner, said Jeremy Fiance, the managing partner at The House Fund, in an email interview with TechCrunch.<\/p>\n “We’re called The House Fund because we’re the home for the Berkeley startup community,” Fiance said. “We support Berkeley people in their entrepreneurial journey, whether that\u2019s joining startups, starting startups, advising them, providing feedback on their ideas well before any startup materializes and so much more.”<\/p>\n Fund III will invest in Berkeley-affiliated AI startups — whether founded by alumni, faculty, PhD candidates, postdoctoral and grad students, recent graduates, undergraduates or dropouts.<\/p>\n Roughly 70% of Fund III will go toward startups at the pre-seed stage, Fiance says. But The House Fund will also lead, co-lead and participate in seed rounds and “consider” a “small number” of first-round Series A rounds with founders who’ve had previous exits worth $500 million to over $1 billion.<\/p>\n “We write first checks up to $2 million and reserve for follow-ons,” Fiance added. “We can write a check as small as $100,000 in a recently graduated founder or dropout and are fine being the only investor, for example.”<\/p>\n The House Fund, launched in 2016, claims to be the “first-ever fund” focused on Berkeley startups and the only fund backed by both the University of California System Endowment and UC Berkeley’s campus endowment.<\/p> "piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n The House Fund currently has $330 million under management and more than 100 funds have follow-on invested in its startups, Fiance says. (The VC firm’s first fund was $6 million, and its second fund, closed in late 2019, was $44 million.) "font-size: 1rem; letter-spacing: -0.1px;\">Notable investments from The House Fund’s previous funds include "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/10\/21\/anyscale-adds-40m-to-bring-its-ray-based-distributed-computing-tech-to-the-enterprise-masses\/\">Anyscale<\/a>, a company building a framework for distributed compute projects; software development platform "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/01\/25\/crowdbotics-raises-40m-to-help-devs-build-apps-from-modular-code\/\">Crowdbotics<\/a>; and Goldberg’s "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/10\/17\/ambi-robotics-secures-32m-infusion-to-deploy-its-item-sorting-robots-in-warehouses\/\">Ambi Robotics<\/a>.<\/span><\/p>\n “There’s roughly 600,000 Berkeley people — among the biggest alumni bases in the world,” Fiance said. “And there’s been a longstanding ask from most alumni for more accessible community engagement and frictionless ways to unlock from Berkeley as an alum. As a big public school, Berkeley historically hasn\u2019t had the resources to meet this demand. So we took matters into our own hands in service to our community … We exist to meet the needs of entrepreneurs, curating comprehensive resources for Berkeley AI founders and creating the connected environment startups need to thrive.”<\/p>\n Startups that receive backing from The House Fund get access to tech from the VC firm’s partners, mentorship from The House Fund’s LPs and advisors, access to talent from the Berkeley campus and alumni base and introductions to potential customers with Berkeley relationships.<\/p>\n "ltr\">The House Fund also runs an accelerator, recently announced, that provides a handful of companies a $1 million investment each, a $10 million post-money SAFE note and “free and early access” to tech from tech company partners, including OpenAI, Microsoft and Databricks. (SAFE notes give investors the right to purchase equity in a company at some specified date in the future.) The House Fund accelerator participants also get mentorship from Gradient Ventures, Google’s AI-focused venture fund, as well as from The House Fund’s aforementioned tech partners.<\/div>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":" The House Fund, the pre-seed and early-stage venture capital fund focused on UC Berkeley startups, specifically AI startups, today announced that it has closed its third tranche — Fund III — at $115 million. With the close of Fund III, Ken Goldberg, the UC Berkeley professor and prolific roboticist, will join The House Fund as […]<\/p>\n","protected":false},"author":133574536,"featured_media":2135051,"comment_status":"open","ping_status":"closed","sticky":false,"template":"","format":"standard","meta":{"amp_status":"","relegenceEntities":[],"relegenceSubjects":[],"carmot_uuid":"a952810b-4d68-3fcc-9367-052a6b1f5760","footnotes":"","apple_news_api_created_at":"2023-10-25T16:00:17Z","apple_news_api_id":"98bb5375-5c16-4366-bfdc-68f492a84c76","apple_news_api_modified_at":"2023-10-25T22:06:19Z","apple_news_api_revision":"AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAQ==","apple_news_api_share_url":"https:\/\/apple.news\/AmLtTdVwWQ2a_3Gj0kqhMdg","apple_news_coverimage":0,"apple_news_coverimage_caption":"","apple_news_is_hidden":false,"apple_news_is_paid":false,"apple_news_is_preview":false,"apple_news_is_sponsored":false,"apple_news_maturity_rating":"","apple_news_metadata":"\"\"","apple_news_pullquote":"","apple_news_pullquote_position":"","apple_news_slug":"","apple_news_sections":"\"\"","apple_news_suppress_video_url":false,"apple_news_use_image_component":false},"categories":[577047203,20429,577030455],"tags":[14067,55409,20250,449450217,173934,42722,36665853,202],"crunchbase_tag":[],"tc_stories_tax":[],"tc_ec_category":[],"tc_event":[],"tc_regions_tax":[],"yoast_head":"\n uty-ads-for-lip-and-eye-products\/","title":{"rendered":"Google launches AR beauty ads for lip and eye products"},"content":{"rendered":" "speakable-summary\">Google sees augmented reality (AR) as a new, potentially quite effective advertising medium.<\/p>\n Today, the search giant announced the launch of AR Beauty ads, a new smartphone ad type that allows brands to promote lip and eye products (and soon foundation) through “virtual try-on” experiences.<\/p>\n In place of a product image in a standard "https:\/\/support.google.com\/google-ads\/answer\/2454022?hl=en\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Google Shopping<\/a> ad, AR Beauty ads offer a tool that lets consumers preview what different products might look like on themselves or a model that “resonates” with them. The tool is paired with a product description and pricing information, along with a simplified checkout flow designed to streamline the purchasing process.<\/p>\n AR Beauty ads will show up in the mobile-specific channels Google Shopping ads typically do, including the Shopping tab on Google.com, Search and Google Images.<\/p>\n “AR Beauty ads help our beauty brand partners showcase their products in a more interactive way to capture demand,” reads a press release attributed to Lilian Rincon, senior director of consumer shopping at Google, shared with TechCrunch yesterday. “When a new tool is helpful for shoppers, it can be helpful for the entire industry.”<\/p>\n The rollout of AR Beauty ads — which comes as Google debuts virtual try-on tools for hair color and foundation in Search, including a tool that lets users virtually try foundation on themselves — reflects the tech and ad industry’s growing belief in AR as a powerful force for marketing.<\/p>\n "attachment_2619281\" style=\"width: 522px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"> "caption-attachment-2619281\" decoding=\"async\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"size-full wp-image-2619281\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/AR-Beauty-Ads.gif\" alt=\"AR Beauty Ads\" width=\"512\" height=\"507\" \/> "caption-attachment-2619281\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"> Image Credits:<\/strong> Google<\/p><\/div><\/p> "piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n In May, Meta "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/05\/04\/meta-pitches-augmented-reality-to-advertisers-with-new-ar-reels-ads-and-facebook-stories\/\">announced<\/a> that it would roll out AR ads to Instagram Reels and Facebook Stories later this year. (Meta first "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2018\/07\/10\/facebook-ar-ads\/\">tested<\/a> AR ads in the Facebook News Feed in July 2018.) Pok\u00e9mon GO developer Niantic piloted AR ad experiences during the Cannes Lions festival in early spring. And Snapchat has long offered AR ads through its "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/snapchat-ads\/\">Lens<\/a> technology and platform.<\/p>\n AR Beauty ads are something of a follow-up for Google, which way back in 2019 "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2019\/08\/15\/youtubes-new-ar-feature-lets-you-virtually-try-on-makeup-while-watching-videos\/\">brought<\/a> AR to YouTube display ads as a part of an experiment with makeup influencers. Powered by FameBit, Google’s in-house branded content platform, viewers could virtually try on makeup while following along with YouTube creators to get tips and product reviews.<\/p>\n The mad rush isn’t fueled by hype alone — or so brands say.<\/p>\n According to Shopify "https:\/\/www.emodoinc.com\/blog\/the-growing-trend-of-ar-advertising\/#:~:text=According%20to%20data%20from%20Shopify,action%20into%20the%20interactive%20experience.\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">data<\/a>, AR ads often perform better than display ads, with the average 3D AR ad generating 94% higher conversion rates than its static, 2D counterpart. Meanwhile, Snap and Deloitte "https:\/\/deloitte.wsj.com\/riskandcompliance\/augmented-reality-shifts-from-toy-to-practical-tool-01630518417\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">find<\/a> that brands offering AR experiences are 41% more likely to be considered by customers, and that nearly three in four shoppers are were willing to pay more for a product that they can explore with AR.<\/p>\n Google, for its part, said that its 2019 YouTube experiment with VR ads resulted in just under a third of viewers spending over 80 seconds trying on lipstick on average. And the company claims that, after interacting with the virtual try-on tools on Google Search, shoppers are “measurably” more likely to spend time on a brand’s site, research a product or make a purchase.<\/p>\n All those metrics are perhaps why, by 2025, global AR ad revenue is "https:\/\/arinsider.co\/2021\/08\/19\/will-ar-ad-revenue-reach-6-7-billion-by-2025\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">projected<\/a> to grow to $6.68 billion \u2014 a steep increase from 2020, when it totaled $1.36 billion.<\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":" Google sees augmented reality (AR) as a new, potentially quite effective advertising medium. Today, the search giant announced the launch of AR Beauty ads, a new smartphone ad type that allows brands to promote lip and eye products (and soon foundation) through “virtual try-on” experiences. In place of a product image in a standard Google and Technology News","publisher":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#organization"},"alternateName":"TC","potentialAction":[{"@type":"SearchAction","target":{"@type":"EntryPoint","urlTemplate":"https:\/\/search.techcrunch.com\/search?p={search_term_string}"},"query-input":"required name=search_term_string"}],"inLanguage":"en-US"},{"@type":"Organization","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#organization","name":"TechCrunch","alternateName":"TC","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/","logo":{"@type":"ImageObject","inLanguage":"en-US","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","contentUrl":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","width":1200,"height":1200,"caption":"TechCrunch"},"image":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/"},"sameAs":["https:\/\/www.facebook.com\/techcrunch","https:\/\/twitter.com\/TechCrunch","https:\/\/mstdn.social\/@TechCrunch","https:\/\/bsky.app\/profile\/techcrunch.bsky.social","https:\/\/www.threads.net\/@techcrunch"]}]}},"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/1508"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=1508"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_battlefield?tags=1508"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=1508"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_unified_video?tags=1508"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=1508"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2614509,"date":"2023-10-25T06:00:49","date_gmt":"2023-10-25T13:00:49","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2614509"},"modified":"2023-10-25T08:44:01","modified_gmt":"2023-10-25T15:44:01","slug":"centml-lands-27m-from-nvidia-others-to-make-ai-models-run-more-efficiently","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/25\/centml-lands-27m-from-nvidia-others-to-make-ai-models-run-more-efficiently\/","title":{"rendered":"CentML lands $27M from Nvidia, others to make AI models run more efficiently"},"content":{"rendered":" "speakable-summary\">Contrary to what you "https:\/\/news.crunchbase.com\/venture\/seed-series-a-funding-charts-2023\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">might’ve heard<\/a>, the era of large seed rounds isn’t over — at least in the AI sector.<\/p>\n "https:\/\/centml.ai\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">CentML<\/a>, a startup developing tools to decrease the cost — and improve the performance — of deploying machine learning models, this morning announced that it raised $27 million in an extended seed round with participation from Gradient Ventures, TR Ventures, Nvidia and Microsoft Azure AI VP Misha Bilenko.<\/p>\n CentML initially closed its seed round in 2022, but extended the round over the last few months as interest in its product grew — bringing its total raised to $30.5 million.<\/p>\n The fresh capital will be used to bolster CentML’s product development and research efforts in addition to expanding the startup’s engineering team and broader workforce of 30 people spread across the U.S. and Canada, according to CentML co-founder and CEO Gennady Pekhimenko.<\/p>\n Pekhimenko, an associate professor at the University of Toronto, co-founded CentML last year alongside Akbar Nurlybayev and PhD students Shang Wang and Anand Jayarajan. Pekhimenko says that they shared a vision of creating tech that could increase access to compute in the face of the worsening AI chip supply problem.<\/p>\n “Machine learning costs, talent and chip shortages… any AI and machine learning company faces at least one of these challenges, and most face a few at a time,” Pekhimenko told TechCrunch in an email interview. “The highest-end chips are commonly unavailable due to the large demand from enterprises and startups alike. This leads to companies sacrificing on the size of the model they can deploy or results in higher inference latencies for their deployed models.”<\/p>\n Most companies training models, particularly generative AI models like "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/chatgpt\/\">ChatGPT<\/a> and "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/07\/26\/stability-ai-releases-its-latest-image-generating-model-stable-diffusion-xl-1-0\/\">Stable Diffusion<\/a>, rely heavily on GPU-based hardware. GPUs\u2019 ability to perform many computations in parallel make them well-suited to training today\u2019s most capable AI.<\/p> "piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n But there are not enough chips to go around.<\/p>\n Microsoft is facing a shortage of the server hardware needed to run AI so severe that it might lead to service disruptions, the company "https:\/\/www.cnbc.com\/2023\/07\/28\/microsoft-annual-report-highlights-importance-of-gpus.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">warned<\/a> in a summer earnings report. And Nvidia\u2019s best-performing AI cards are "https:\/\/www.barrons.com\/articles\/nvidia-ai-chips-coreweave-cloud-6db44825#:~:text=The%20rising%20excitement%20over%20generative,technology%20industry's%20most%20precious%20resource.\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">reportedly<\/a>\u00a0sold out until 2024.<\/p>\n That’s led some companies, including "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/06\/openai-said-to-be-considering-developing-its-own-ai-chips\/\">OpenAI<\/a>, "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/08\/29\/google-cloud-announces-the-5th-generation-of-its-custom-tpus\/\">Google<\/a>, "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/12\/01\/aws-launches-trainium-its-new-custom-ml-training-chip\/\">AWS<\/a>, "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/05\/18\/meta-bets-big-on-ai-with-custom-chips-and-a-supercomputer\/\">Meta<\/a> and "https:\/\/interestingengineering.com\/innovation\/microsoft-launch-new-chip-athena\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Microsoft<\/a>, to build — or explore building — their own custom chips for model training. But even this hasn’t proven to be a panacea. Meta\u2019s efforts have been beset with issues, leading the company to scrap some of its experimental hardware. And Google hasn\u2019t managed to keep pace with demand for its cloud-hosted, homegrown GPU equivalent, the tensor processing unit (TPU), Wired "https:\/\/www.wired.com\/story\/nvidia-chip-shortages-leave-ai-startups-scrambling-for-computing-power\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">reported<\/a> recently.<\/p>\n With spending on AI-focused chips expected to hit $53 billion this year and more than double in the next four years, "https:\/\/www.gartner.com\/en\/newsroom\/press-releases\/2023-08-22-gartner-forecasts-worldwide-ai-chips-revenue-to-reach-53-billion-dollars-in-2023\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">according<\/a> to Gartner, Pekhimenko felt the time was right to launch software that could make models run more efficiently on existing hardware.<\/p>\n “Training AI and machine learning models is increasingly expensive,” Pekhimenko said. “With CentML\u2019s optimization technology, we’re able to reduce expenses up to 80% without compromising speed or accuracy.”<\/p>\n That’s quite a claim. But at a high level, CentML’s software is relatively easy to make sense of.<\/p>\n The platform attempts to identify bottlenecks during model training and predict the total time and cost to deploy a model. Beyond this, CentML provides access to a compiler — a component that translates a programming language’s source code into machine code that hardware like a GPU can understand — to automatically optimize model training workloads to perform best on target hardware.<\/p>\n Pekhimenko claims that CentML’s software doesn’t degrade models and requires “little to no effort” for engineers to use.<\/p>\n “For one of our customers, we optimized their "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/07\/18\/meta-releases-llama-2-a-more-helpful-set-of-text-generating-models\/\">Llama 2<\/a> model to work 3x faster by using Nvidia A10 GPU cards,” she added.<\/p>\n CentML isn’t the first to take a software-based approach to model optimization. It has competitors in "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/06\/26\/databricks-picks-up-mosaicml-an-openai-competitor-for-1-3b\/\">MosaicML<\/a>, which Databricks acquired in June for $1.3 billion, and "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/11\/01\/octoml-raises-85m-for-it-for-its-machine-learning-acceleration-platform\/\">OctoML<\/a>, which landed an $85 million cash infusion in November 2021 for its machine learning acceleration platform.<\/p>\n But Pekhimenko asserts that CentML’s techniques don’t result in a loss of model accuracy, like MosaicML’s can sometimes do, and that CentML’s compiler is “newer generation” and more performant than OctoML’s compiler.<\/p>\n In the near future, CentML plans to turn its attention to optimizing not only model training but inference — i.e. running models after they’ve been trained. GPUs are heavily used in inference today as well, and Pekhimenko sees it as a potential avenue of growth for the company.<\/p>\n “The CentML platform can run any model,” Pekhimenko said. “CentML produces optimized code for a variety of GPUs and reduces the memory needed to deploy models, and, as such, allows teams to deploy on smaller and cheaper GPUs.”<\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":" Contrary to what you might’ve heard, the era of large seed rounds isn’t over — at least in the AI sector. CentML, a startup developing tools to decrease the cost — and improve the performance — of deploying machine learning models, this morning announced that it raised $27 million in an extended seed round with 3\/10\/25\/grammarlys-new-generative-ai-feature-learns-your-style-and-applies-it-to-any-text\/","title":{"rendered":"Grammarly’s new generative AI feature learns your style — and applies it to any text"},"content":{"rendered":" "speakable-summary\">As generative AI becomes embedded in the platforms we use every day, debates are swirling around who should get credit — and compensation — for AI-generated works.<\/p>\n YouTube is in the "https:\/\/www.theverge.com\/2023\/8\/21\/23840026\/youtube-ai-music-copyright-monetization-universal\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">process<\/a> of hashing out licensing agreements with record labels to use musicians’ voices to create new music in their styles. Meanwhile, some art-generating AI platforms are "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/07\/11\/shutterstock-expands-deal-with-openai-to-build-generative-ai-tools\/\">figuring<\/a> "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/09\/25\/getty-images-launches-an-ai-powered-image-generator\/\">out<\/a> "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/10\/adobe-firefly-can-now-generate-more-realistic-images\/\">ways<\/a> to pay artists for their contributions to the data used to train the platforms’ AI models.<\/p>\n But what about text? Should — and if so, how<\/em> should — writers be recognized and remunerated for AI-generated works that mimic their voices?<\/p>\n Those are questions that are likely to be raised by a feature in Grammarly, the cloud-based typing assistant, that’s scheduled to launch by the end of the year for subscribers to Grammarly’s business tier. Called “Personalized voice detection and application,” the feature automatically detects a person’s unique writing style and creates a “voice profile” that can rewrite any text in the person’s style.<\/p>\n “Because Grammarly works across apps and tools, we can understand a user\u2019s unique style and preferences in the places they communicate to generate a personalized profile,” Tal Oppenheimer, head of product for Grammarly’s client apps, told TechCrunch in an email interview. “We generate a person\u2019s profile as they passively use our product.”<\/p>\n Oppenheimer says that each profile, which comes with an AI-generated description that highlights what Grammarly sees as the defining characteristics of the person’s style (e.g. “positive,” “encouraging”), can be customized to a certain degree. Users can discard elements such as tone and style choices — say, a tendency to use active voice and compound sentences — that they believe don’t accurately reflect the way they write.<\/p>\n "attachment_2618996\" style=\"width: 1034px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"> "caption-attachment-2618996\" decoding=\"async\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"size-full wp-image-2618996\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/image007-2.png\" alt=\"Grammarly\" width=\"1024\" height=\"1024\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/image007-2.png 1080w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/image007-2.png?resize=150,150 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/image007-2.png?resize=300,300 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/image007-2.png?resize=768,768 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/image007-2.png?resize=680,680 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/image007-2.png?resize=32,32 32w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/image007-2.png?resize=50,50 50w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/image007-2.png?resize=64,64 64w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/image007-2.png?resize=96,96 96w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/image007-2.png?resize=128,128 128w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px\" \/> "caption-attachment-2618996\" class=\"wp-caption-text\">Grammarly’s new voice profile feature, which uses generative AI to match the style of a person’s writing.
Image Credits:<\/strong> Grammarly<\/p><\/div><\/p> "piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n “As this is the first release of our personalized voice features, we\u2019ll continue to refine them over time and consider ways to make them even more personalized to customers and their needs,” Oppenheimer said.<\/p>\n Grammarly pitches the tech as a way for writers to leverage context to “make [their] writing sound more personal.” But this<\/em> writer worries about how it might be used in considerably less charitable ways.<\/p>\n Imagine a company tapping a Grammarly voice profile while a writer’s on leave — or after they’ve been let go — to publish blog posts under their byline without their approval and without compensating them. Or, picture a Grammarly voice profile being used to impersonate someone in a sophisticated phishing attempt.<\/p>\n It’s not as far-fetched as it sounds. Author Jane Friedman "https:\/\/www.cnn.com\/2023\/08\/10\/tech\/ai-generated-books-amazon\/index.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">discovered<\/a> in August that new books were being sold on Amazon under her name — new books that she didn’t write, and that appeared to have been generated by AI. (Amazon later removed the fake books and said that its policies prohibit such imitation.)<\/p>\n Grammarly isn’t the first to bring to the fore the issue of writer protections where they pertain to generative AI, of course.
"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/07\/18\/thousands-of-authors-sign-letter-urging-ai-makers-to-stop-stealing-books\/\" data-mrf-link=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/07\/18\/thousands-of-authors-sign-letter-urging-ai-makers-to-stop-stealing-books\/\">Thousands<\/a> of authors recently signed an open letter decrying generative AI technologies that “mimic and regurgitate” their “language, stories, style and ideas.” Writers in California and New York, meanwhile, have gone a step further, "https:\/\/apnews.com\/article\/openai-lawsuit-authors-grisham-george-rr-martin-37f9073ab67ab25b7e6b2975b2a63bfe#:~:text=NEW%20YORK%20(AP)%20%E2%80%94%20John,their%20copyrighted%20works%20without%20permission.\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-mrf-link=\"https:\/\/apnews.com\/article\/openai-lawsuit-authors-grisham-george-rr-martin-37f9073ab67ab25b7e6b2975b2a63bfe#:~:text=NEW%20YORK%20(AP)%20%E2%80%94%20John,their%20copyrighted%20works%20without%20permission.\">suing<\/a> AI startup OpenAI — which they say trained text-generating AI on their work without permission — over alleged IP theft.<\/p>\n Now, to be fair to Grammarly, not just anyone can access a Grammarly voice profile. At least at launch, individual users can only use their corresponding voice profile — not anyone else’s. And they can’t be exported.<\/p>\n I do worry, though, about how voice profiles might evolve down the line given Grammarly’s emphasis on cost savings in its marketing materials. Conceivably, in the pursuit of cost cutting, a Grammarly-subscribed business will eventually want access to all of its writers’ profiles. Will Grammarly deny them? Who’s to say?<\/p>\n For her part, Oppenheimer stressed that voice profiles “aren’t designed to replace anybody.”<\/p>\n “Rather than imitate them, [voice profiles] helps [writers] learn about how they sound, create more personalized output and write in a more authentic way.”<\/p>\n Call me skeptical, but I’m very wary.<\/p>\n Personalized voice detection and application joins Grammarly’s other generative AI features, many of which are entering general availability this week. The company, which has more than 30 million users and over 70,000 teams on its platforms, says that users are creating over 12 million pieces of content weekly with the features.<\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":" As generative AI becomes embedded in the platforms we use every day, debates are swirling around who should get credit — and compensation — for AI-generated works. YouTube is in the process of hashing out licensing agreements with record labels to use musicians’ voices to create new music in their styles. Meanwhile, some art-generating AI […]<\/p>\n","protected":false},"author":133574536,"featured_media":2522564,"comment_status":"open","ping_status":"closed","sticky":false,"template":"","format":"standard","meta":{"amp_status":"","relegenceEntities":[],"relegenceSubjects":[],"carmot_uuid":"27047314-3cbd-3a12-894d-5a26f9f07891","footnotes":"","apple_news_api_created_at":"2023-10-25T13:00:57Z","apple_news_api_id":"674bc3ce-216e-4917-ab14-f978612b985d","apple_news_api_modified_at":"2023-10-25T13:00:57Z","apple_news_api_revision":"AAAAAAAAAAD\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/w==","apple_news_api_share_url":"https:\/\/apple.news\/AZ0vDziFuSRerFPl4YSuYXQ","apple_news_coverimage":0,"apple_news_coverimage_caption":"","apple_news_is_hidden":false,"apple_news_is_paid":false,"apple_news_is_preview":false,"apple_news_is_sponsored":false,"apple_news_maturity_rating":"","apple_news_metadata":"\"\"","apple_news_pullquote":"","apple_news_pullquote_position":"","apple_news_slug":"","apple_news_sections":"\"\"","apple_news_suppress_video_url":false,"apple_news_use_image_component":false},"categories":[577047203,449557044,577030456],"tags":[14067,576717904,465451554],"crunchbase_tag":[],"tc_stories_tax":[],"tc_ec_category":[],"tc_event":[],"tc_regions_tax":[],"yoast_head":"\n TechCrunch","inLanguage":"en-US","isAccessibleForFree":"True","hasPart":{"@type":"WebPageElement","isAccessibleForFree":"True"}},{"@type":"WebSite","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#website","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/","name":"TechCrunch","description":"Startup and Technology News","publisher":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#organization"},"alternateName":"TC","potentialAction":[{"@type":"SearchAction","target":{"@type":"EntryPoint","urlTemplate":"https:\/\/search.techcrunch.com\/search?p={search_term_string}"},"query-input":"required name=search_term_string"}],"inLanguage":"en-US"},{"@type":"Organization","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#organization","name":"TechCrunch","alternateName":"TC","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/","logo":{"@type":"ImageObject","inLanguage":"en-US","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","contentUrl":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","width":1200,"height":1200,"caption":"TechCrunch"},"image":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/"},"sameAs":["https:\/\/www.facebook.com\/techcrunch","https:\/\/twitter.com\/TechCrunch","https:\/\/mstdn.social\/@TechCrunch","https:\/\/bsky.app\/profile\/techcrunch.bsky.social","https:\/\/www.threads.net\/@techcrunch"]}]}},"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/465451554"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=465451554"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_battlefield?tags=465451554"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=465451554"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_unified_video?tags=465451554"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=465451554"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2618305,"date":"2023-10-25T06:00:35","date_gmt":"2023-10-25T13:00:35","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2618305"},"modified":"2023-10-25T09:14:48","modified_gmt":"2023-10-25T16:14:48","slug":"eve-launches-to-bring-llms-to-the-legal-profession","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/25\/eve-launches-to-bring-llms-to-the-legal-profession\/","title":{"rendered":"Eve launches to bring LLMs to the legal profession"},"content":{"rendered":" "speakable-summary\">In 2020, Jay Madheswaran, Matt Noe and David Zeng, all veterans of the tech industry, had a vision to harness the power of large language models (\u00e0 la OpenAI’s ChatGPT) to shake up the legal profession. Their goal was to create a platform that’d enable lawyers to be more productive by abstracting away processes around legal discovery and research.<\/p>\n “Legal professionals dedicate hours of their day manually sifting through documents to extract relevant insights,” Madheswaran told TechCrunch in an email interview. “This work is not only becoming unmanageable; it\u2019s costing law firms a significant amount of money.”<\/p>\n To Madheswaran’s point, one "https:\/\/metajure.com\/lawyers-waste-six-hours-a-week-on-document-management-issues-2\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">survey<\/a> — albeit a quite dated one, from 2012 — found that “information workers” in the legal profession, including lawyers and paralegals, spend more than 11 hours a week dealing with challenges related to document creation and management, at least six hours of which is wasted time. All told, time wasted in document creation and management activities cost firms $9,071 per lawyer a year, amounting to nearly $1 million for a firm with 100 lawyers, the study found.<\/p>\n So Madheswaran — who previously was an early-stage investor in Lightspeed Venture Partners and, before that, the head of engineering at Rubrik, where het met Noe (then the lead for Rubrik’s machine learning products) and Zeng (a Rubrik engineer) — founded "https:\/\/www.eve.legal\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Eve<\/a>, an AI-powered platform designed to handle legal tasks like document review, case analysis, client intake and research.<\/p>\n Eve today emerged from stealth with $14 million from Lightspeed Ventures — Madheswaran’s old firm — and Menlo Ventures.<\/p>\n “Eve can be fine-tuned to meet the evolving demands and variety of case work at any given firm,” Madheswaran said. “Our platform comes pre-trained with skills and knowledge specific to the legal profession, which means law professionals can derive value right out of the box — without any engineering work required.”<\/p>\n Eve comes with a set of apps aimed at automating what Madheswaran describes as “low-value” use cases for litigation, transactional law and specific practice areas. Customers can fine-tune and customize the apps for specific practice areas and applications, Madheswaran says, and embed Eve in their firm’s day-to-day tasks and workflows.<\/p> "piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n Lest a lawyer or paralegal be concerned that Eve starts to “ "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/09\/04\/are-language-models-doomed-to-always-hallucinate\/\">hallucinate<\/a>” — the tendency generative AI models have to make things up — Madheswaran emphasizes that the platform is “built to encourage full citations” and direct quotes, and always prompt users to validate the results of its work.<\/p>\n “Eve can scale and evolve alongside a law practice,” Madheswaran said. “There’s no configuration or extensive onboarding needed.”<\/p>\n Now, Eve is but one of many “AI assistant” products emerging in the legal market. To name a few of its rivals, there’s "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/11\/23\/harvey-which-uses-ai-to-answer-legal-questions-lands-cash-from-openai\/\">Harvey<\/a>, which uses AI to answer legal questions; "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/03\/01\/zero-systems-gets-12m-series-a-to-bring-automation-to-professional-services\/\">Zero Systems<\/a>, with seeks to bring automation to professional services including law firms; and generative AI platform "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/06\/26\/thomson-reuters-buys-casetext-an-ai-legal-tech-startup-for-650m-in-cash\/\">Casetex<\/a>, which Thomson Reuters acquired in August for $650 million.<\/p>\n But Eve’s competitors face the same challenges: convincing firms to embrace the tech. According to a recent "https:\/\/wislawjournal.com\/2023\/10\/16\/lawyers-remain-cautious-about-embracing-ai-in-practices\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">poll<\/a> by the Association of Corporate Counsel and the Wisconsin-based law firm Lowenstein Sandler, only 64% of in-house counsel have used AI for legal tasks. Those who haven’t adopted it cited legal risks and ethical concerns as the top blockers.<\/p>\n Eve’s had some success so far, however, with a customer base that numbers “over a dozen” firms with “several hundred lawyers” under their employ. The 15-person startup plans to use the proceeds from its latest funding round to “double down” on product development and go-to-market functions, according to Madheswaran.<\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":" In 2020, Jay Madheswaran, Matt Noe and David Zeng, all veterans of the tech industry, had a vision to harness the power of large language models (\u00e0 la OpenAI’s ChatGPT) to shake up the legal profession. Their goal was to create a platform that’d enable lawyers to be more productive by abstracting away processes around \/censys-lands-new-cash-to-grow-its-threat-detecting-cybersecurity-service\/","title":{"rendered":"Censys lands new cash to grow its threat-detecting cybersecurity service"},"content":{"rendered":" "speakable-summary\">Investments in cybersecurity companies are beginning to turn a corner, seemingly.<\/p>\n After a "https:\/\/news.crunchbase.com\/cybersecurity\/venture-funding-falls-q2-2023\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">brutal summer<\/a>, VC funding to security startups saw a slight (12%) uptick from Q3, "https:\/\/news.crunchbase.com\/cybersecurity\/vc-funding-q3-bounce-back-2023\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">according<\/a> to Crunchbase — reaching nearly $1.9 billion compared to $1.7 billion in the second quarter. That’s still down 30% annually. But it’s a tepid sign that venture’s appetite for cyber is growing anew.<\/p>\n Increasing enterprise cybersecurity budgets could be the reason.<\/p>\n "https:\/\/www.securitymagazine.com\/articles\/99943-report-shows-cybersecurity-budgets-increased-6-for-2022-2023-cycle#:~:text=Report%20shows%20cybersecurity%20budgets%20increased%206%25%20for%202022%2D2023%20cycle,-By%20Security%20Staff&text=IANS%20Research%20and%20Artico%20Search,analyzes%20detailed%20cybersecurity%20budget%20data.\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Per an<\/a> IANS Research report, corporate budgets for IT security grew 6% between 2022 and 2023 — a modest but noteworthy amount. Most respondents cited “increased risk” and “digital transformation” — i.e. digitizing legacy apps, products and services —\u00a0 as the motivators behind the budget upticks.<\/p>\n One startup to benefit from all this is "https:\/\/search.censys.io\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Censys<\/a>, which provides customers with insights about critical internet-connected infrastructure. Censys this morning announced that it raised $50 million in a Series C funding round plus a $25 million debt round, bringing its total raised to $128.1 million.<\/p>\n Decibel Partners led the round with participation from GV, Greylock and Intel Capital. Other participants included Ascension Ventures, Four Rivers Partners V, L.P. and accounts managed by Hamilton Lane.<\/p>\n Censys has its roots in an internet scanning program, ZMap, developed by the company’s chief scientist Zakir Durumeric in 2013. By 2015, after coming to the realization that the software could be used to actually improve, rather than simply monitor, the state of security online, Durumeric had assembled a team to refine and improve ZMap’s capabilities.<\/p> "piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n “We believe that perfect visibility of anything exposed to the internet is the only way to allow individuals and organizations to protect themselves from external threats,” Brad Brooks, Censys’ CEO, told TechCrunch in an email interview. “With the help of early investors, including Google Ventures, Greylock, Decibel and Intel Capital, our mission evolved, and we set out to create the best, most comprehensive, internet scanning engine in the world.”<\/p>\n Today, Censys offers a range of tools to keep tabs on internet hosts and services and their security statuses. Customers get a database of vulnerable infrastructure “enriched with context,” as well as a platform for monitoring and analyzing their internet-facing assets (e.g. servers and desktops).<\/p>\n Brooks says that most customers use the platform for threat hunting — that is, spotting and investigating signs of security compromise — and triaging exploits detected through Censys’ asset monitoring tech. Some also tap Censys to understand the impact of their security efforts, according to Brooks, including the duration and severity of risks.<\/p>\n “Powered by leading internet intelligence, Censys gives leaders and their teams the data and capabilities needed to stay ahead of advanced threat actors,” Brooks said. “They can use Censys’ benchmarks to track performance over time and generate industry-standard metrics.”<\/p>\n Recently — climbing aboard the generative AI hype train — Censys launched a chatbot that enables users to perform searches across its security database in natural language. For example, they can ask things like “Show me all servers in Australia that have both FTP and HTTP services” to have the platform surface the corresponding data. Or they can have the chatbot translate search syntax from a third-party threat-hunting platform, like Shodan or Zoomeye, into a format that Censys can understand.<\/p>\n Censys, which claims to have 350,000 users on its free service and over 180 paying customers, including government agencies ranging from the FBI to the Department of Homeland Security, plans to put the proceeds from the most recent funding toward expanding its 134-person workforce. By the end of 2023, Censys — which is based in Ann Arbor, Michigan — expects to have 150 employees.<\/p>\n “We’re lucky in that cybersecurity is still in high demand despite economic uncertainty,” Brooks said. “In fact, the pandemic provided a tailwind as major enterprises had to shift to cloud solutions and resituate thousands to a remote work setup, which drove demand and inquiries.”<\/p>\n The challenge for Censys will maintaining momentum in the face of increasingly strong headwinds.<\/p>\n Issues in Europe and between the U.S. and China threaten to keep venture funding in cyber relatively flat — or possibly even in decline — for the remainder of the year. Higher interest rates are hurting the ability for investors to raise new funds, in turn hurting startups’ ability to raise money.<\/p>\n Meanwhile, hedge funds, late-stage and crossover funds that invest in both public and private companies have "https:\/\/www.thelowdownblog.com\/2022\/06\/why-venture-funding-in-cybersecurity-is.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">pulled back<\/a> from the cyber market over fears of a recession — and disruption in the wider tech market.<\/p>\n On the other hand — as alluded to earlier — there’s "https:\/\/www.spiceworks.com\/research\/state-of-it\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">reason<\/a> for optimism.<\/p>\n "https:\/\/www.spiceworks.com\/research\/state-of-it\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">According<\/a> to a recent Spiceworks report, while the vast majority of companies are concerned about a recession in 2024, two-thirds (66%) still intend to increase their year-on-year IT spend, including spending on cybersecurity, while only 4% plan to decrease their spend. And IDC "https:\/\/www.cybersecuritydive.com\/news\/cybersecurity-spending-increase-idc\/645338\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">predicts<\/a> that global cybersecurity spending will top $219 billion this year, growing to nearly $300 billion in 2026.<\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":" Investments in cybersecurity companies are beginning to turn a corner, seemingly. After a brutal summer, VC funding to security startups saw a slight (12%) uptick from Q3, according to Crunchbase — reaching nearly $1.9 billion compared to $1.7 billion in the second quarter. That’s still down 30% annually. But it’s a tepid sign that venture’s […]<\/p>\n","protected":false},"author":133574536,"featured_media":2591434,"comment_status":"open","ping_status":"closed","sticky":false,"template":"","format":"standard","meta":{"amp_status":"","relegenceEntities":[],"relegenceSubjects":[],"carmot_uuid":"5ad813fd-0ea6-3473-96cc-b0787fba232b","footnotes":"","apple_news_api_created_at":"2023-10-24T13:01:00Z","apple_news_api_id":"c7ffd1c7-0655-4868-83e2-f42c8c376949","apple_news_api_modified_at":"2023-10-24T23:39:08Z","apple_news_api_revision":"AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAw==","apple_news_api_share_url":"https:\/\/apple.news\/Ax__RxwZVSGiD4vQsjDdpSQ","apple_news_coverimage":0,"apple_news_coverimage_caption":"","apple_news_is_hidden":false,"apple_news_is_paid":false,"apple_news_is_preview":false,"apple_news_is_sponsored":false,"apple_news_maturity_rating":"","apple_news_metadata":"\"\"","apple_news_pullquote":"","apple_news_pullquote_position":"","apple_news_slug":"","apple_news_sections":"\"\"","apple_news_suppress_video_url":false,"apple_news_use_image_component":false},"categories":[21587494,20429],"tags":[576794093,449555503,965824,576785808,20250,801,4621],"crunchbase_tag":[],"tc_stories_tax":[],"tc_ec_category":[],"tc_event":[],"tc_regions_tax":[],"yoast_head":"\n name=search_term_string"}],"inLanguage":"en-US"},{"@type":"Organization","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#organization","name":"TechCrunch","alternateName":"TC","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/","logo":{"@type":"ImageObject","inLanguage":"en-US","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","contentUrl":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","width":1200,"height":1200,"caption":"TechCrunch"},"image":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/"},"sameAs":["https:\/\/www.facebook.com\/techcrunch","https:\/\/twitter.com\/TechCrunch","https:\/\/mstdn.social\/@TechCrunch","https:\/\/bsky.app\/profile\/techcrunch.bsky.social","https:\/\/www.threads.net\/@techcrunch"]}]}},"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/4621"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=4621"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_battlefield?tags=4621"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=4621"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_unified_video?tags=4621"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=4621"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2616492,"date":"2023-10-24T06:00:17","date_gmt":"2023-10-24T13:00:17","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2616492"},"modified":"2023-10-24T09:20:12","modified_gmt":"2023-10-24T16:20:12","slug":"twelve-labs-is-building-models-that-can-understand-videos-at-a-deep-level","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/24\/twelve-labs-is-building-models-that-can-understand-videos-at-a-deep-level\/","title":{"rendered":"Twelve Labs is building models that can understand videos at a deep level"},"content":{"rendered":" "speakable-summary\">Text-generating AI is one thing. But AI models that understand images as well as text can unlock powerful new applications.<\/p>\n Take, for example, Twelve Labs. The San Francisco-based startup trains AI models to — as co-founder and CEO Jae Lee puts it — “solve complex video-language alignment problems.”<\/p>\n “Twelve Labs was founded … "font-size: 1rem; letter-spacing: -0.1px;\"> to create an infrastructure for multimodal video understanding, with the first endeavor being semantic search — or ‘CTRL+F for videos,’<\/span>” Lee told TechCrunch in an email interview. “The "font-size: 1rem; letter-spacing: -0.1px;\">vision of Twelve Labs is to help developers build programs that can see, listen and understand the world as we do.”<\/span><\/p>\n Twelve Labs’ models attempt to map natural language to what’s happening inside a video, including actions, objects and background sounds, allowing developers to create apps that can search through videos, classify scenes and extract topics from within those videos, automatically summarize and split video clips into chapters, and more.<\/p>\n Lee says that Twelve Labs’ technology can drive things like ad insertion and content moderation — for instance, figuring out which videos showing knives are violent versus instructional. It can also be used for media analytics, Lee added, and to automatically generate highlight reels — or blog post headlines and tags — from videos.<\/p>\n I asked Lee about the potential for bias in these models, given that it’s well-established science that models amplify the biases in the data on which they’re trained. For example, training a video understanding model "font-size: 1rem; letter-spacing: -0.1px;\"> on mostly clips of local news — which often spends a lot of time covering crime in a <\/span> "background-color: #ffffff; font-size: 1rem; letter-spacing: -0.1px;\" href=\"https:\/\/www.vox.com\/2015\/6\/3\/8709207\/media-racial-bias-study\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">sensationalized<\/a>, "https:\/\/www.semanticscholar.org\/paper\/Crime-News-and-Racialized-Beliefs%3A-Understanding-of-Dixon\/e5a1c464e4e89a608dd36df19fad3ace2445ebb4\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">racialized<\/a> way — could "font-size: 1rem; letter-spacing: -0.1px;\">cause the model to learn "https:\/\/venturebeat.com\/business\/this-ai-system-learned-to-understand-videos-by-watching-youtube\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">racist as well as sexist patterns<\/a>.<\/span><\/p>\n Lee says that Twelve Labs strives to meet internal bias and “fairness” metrics for its models before releasing them, and that the company plans to release model-ethics-related benchmarks and data sets in the future. But he had nothing to share beyond that.<\/p> "piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n "attachment_2285095\" style=\"width: 1034px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"> "caption-attachment-2285095\" decoding=\"async\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"size-full wp-image-2285095\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/TwelveLabs_Finetune-API1.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1024\" height=\"588\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/TwelveLabs_Finetune-API1.png 1272w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/TwelveLabs_Finetune-API1.png?resize=150,86 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/TwelveLabs_Finetune-API1.png?resize=300,172 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/TwelveLabs_Finetune-API1.png?resize=768,441 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/TwelveLabs_Finetune-API1.png?resize=680,391 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/TwelveLabs_Finetune-API1.png?resize=1200,690 1200w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/TwelveLabs_Finetune-API1.png?resize=50,29 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px\" \/> "caption-attachment-2285095\" class=\"wp-caption-text\">Mockup of API for fine tuning the model to work better with salad-related content.
Image Credits:<\/strong> Twelve Labs<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n “In terms of how our product is different from large language models [like ChatGPT], ours is specifically trained and built to process and understand video, holistically integrating visual, audio and speech components within videos,” Lee said. “We have really pushed the technical limits of what is possible for video understanding.”<\/p>\n Google is developing a similar multimodal model for video understanding called "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/09\/29\/google-introduces-a-new-way-to-search-that-combines-images-and-text-into-one-query\/\">MUM<\/a>, which the company’s using to power video recommendations across Google Search and YouTube. Beyond MUM, Google — as well as Microsoft and Amazon — offer API-level, AI-powered services that recognize objects, places and actions in videos and extract rich metadata at the frame level.<\/p>\n But Lee argues that Twelve Labs is differentiated both by the quality of its models and the platform’s fine-tuning features, which allow customers to automate the platform’s models with their own data for “domain-specific” video analysis.<\/p>\n On the model front, Twelve Labs is today unveiling Pegasus-1, a new multimodal model that understands a range of prompts related to whole-video analysis. For example, Pegasus-1 can be prompted to generate a long, descriptive report about a video or just a few highlights with timestamps.<\/p>\n “Enterprise organizations recognize the potential of leveraging their vast video data for new business opportunities … However, the limited and simplistic capabilities of conventional video AI models often fall short of catering to the intricate understanding required for most business use cases,” Lee said. “Leveraging powerful multimodal video understanding foundation models, enterprise organizations can attain human-level video comprehension without manual analysis.”<\/p>\n Since launching in private beta in early May, Twelve Labs’ user base has grown to 17,000 developers, Lee claims. And the company’s now working with a number of companies — it’s unclear how many; Lee wouldn’t say — across industries including sports, media and entertainment, e-learning and security, including the NFL.<\/p>\n Twelve Labs is also continuing to raise money — and important part of any startup business. Today, the company announced that it closed a $10 million strategic funding round from Nvidia, Intel and Samsung Next, bringing its total raised to $27 million.<\/p>\n “This new investment is all about strategic partners that can accelerate our company in research (compute), product and distribution,” Lee said. “It’s fuel for ongoing innovation, based on our lab\u2019s research, in the field of video understanding so that we can continue to bring the most powerful models to customers, whatever their use cases may be … We’re moving the industry forward in ways that free companies up to do incredible things.”<\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":" Text-generating AI is one thing. But AI models that understand images as well as text can unlock powerful new applications. Take, for example, Twelve Labs. The San Francisco-based startup trains AI models to — as co-founder and CEO Jae Lee puts it — “solve complex video-language alignment problems.” “Twelve Labs was founded … to create […]<\/p>\n","protected":false},"author":133574536,"featured_media":2088075,"comment_status":"open","ping_status":"closed","sticky":false,"template":"","format":"standard","meta":{"amp_status":"","relegenceEntities":[],"relegenceSubjects":[],"carmot_uuid":"1d4f7f43-b55f-38d7-bae3-7b14e169f568","footnotes":"","apple_news_api_created_at":"2023-10-24T13:00:25Z","apple_news_api_id":"7ca5a1d0-e43d-4cfa-b48b-a0687737fa69","apple_news_api_modified_at":"2023-10-24T16:20:07Z","apple_news_api_revision":"AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAA==","apple_news_api_share_url":"https:\/\/apple.news\/AfKWh0OQ9TPq0i6Bodzf6aQ","apple_news_coverimage":0,"apple_news_coverimage_caption":"","apple_news_is_hidden":false,"apple_news_is_paid":false,"apple_news_is_preview":false,"apple_news_is_sponsored":false,"apple_news_maturity_rating":"","apple_news_metadata":"\"\"","apple_news_pullquote":"","apple_news_pullquote_position":"","apple_news_slug":"","apple_news_sections":"\"\"","apple_news_suppress_video_url":false,"apple_news_use_image_component":false},"categories":[577047203,20429],"tags":[14067,20250,576717904,12068,35186,449557485,4621,576994912],"crunchbase_tag":[],"tc_stories_tax":[],"tc_ec_category":[],"tc_event":[],"tc_regions_tax":[],"yoast_head":"\n Twelve Labs is building models that can understand videos at a deep level | TechCrunch<\/title>\n "description\" content=\"Twelve Labs, based in San Francisco, is building AI models to understand videos.
